div.p: THE DISAPPOINTMENT OR THE Mother in Fashion. A PLAY As it was ACTED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL. WRITTEN BY THOMAS SOƲTHERNE.

q.l: Sed longè sequere, & vestigia semper adora.

div.p: LONDON: Printed for Jo. Hindmarsh, Bookseller to his Royal Highness, at the Black Bull in Cornhil. 1684.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONORABLE JAMES Earl of OSSORY.
div.p:
THe imputation that lies on Dedications, is general: and wehther the ill nature of the Age has traduc'd the honest intentions of the Writers; or they, by their fulsom corruptions, to their own wrong, having justly fix'd the Scandal upon themselves, your Lordship may determine: This I believe, a Poet may praise his Patron out of countenance, and a Lover look his Mistris into the confusion of a Blush, and with as little Wit on one hand, as Passion on t' other. The fear of falling under the Justice of this censure, has awed me: and nothing, but the zeal of confessing my self, every way your Servant, (having hardly scap'd the venture of the Stage) cou'd perswade me to throw my self, for a forgiveness, upon a second trial of the Town. The reason of my cause has hardned me
against the malice of detraction, and over-rul'd my fears to a Dedication. The Name of Ossory, I know, will draw every Reader into an expectation of a Panegyrick; and not to rage under the inspiration of that Theme, is grosness, and brutal stupidity, to be shun'd of all the World; and here unpardonable, as wou'd be my impudence, should I undertake it. The vertues of your famous Ancestors, my Lord, live fresh among us; and while the English Chronicle survives, the Ormond worth can never be forgotten; your Grandfather, in every glorious Action, through the whole Story, must begin the Page, shine out, and shew the leading Heroe there. Fortune has once been just, and joining with the wishes of all good men, contriv'd to make the Happiness of your Lordships life, answer the Quality of your House; and to the Nobility of your Birth (made yet more noble by the accession of your Father's Glories) (which you of right inherit, and which your forward Vertue, this Summer promises to maintain) provided you a Lady, whom Nature, in the profusion of her bounty, seems to have made, and only meant for you; to share that greatness, which only Descent, Vertue, Wit, and Beauty, like hers, cou'd deserve. My Lord, you are now launch'd out into the Ocean of this life; and may prosperous gales, and smiling Summer
Seas attend you: may your course be steady; still pointing to that genuine Loyalty (the natural vertue of your Family) which your Forefathers nobly try'd, and found the only Goal of Glory: these, with my Prayers for your long life, and happy, safe return, are the constant, and shall be the daily wishes of

closer.signed: Your Lordships entirely faithful Humble Servant, Tho. Southerne.

div.head: THE DISAPPOINTMENT, OR THE Mother in Fashion.
A SONG written by the Honourable Colonel Sackvile.

lg.l: I Never saw a face till now,
That could my Passion move:
I lik'd, and ventur'd many a Vow,
But durst not think of Love,
Till Beauty, charming every sense,
An easie Conquest made;
And shew'd the vainness of defence,
Where Phyllis does invade.
But Oh! her colder Heart denies
The thoughts, her looks inspire;
And while in Ice that frozen lies,
Her Eyes dart only fire.
Betwixt extreams I am undone,
Like plants too Northward set;
Burnt by too violent a Sun,
Or chill'd for want of heat.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: THe World may laugh at these laborious follies,
That wear away the Day; And so may I,
When my full veins are ebbing into Time;
When Age shall level me to Impotence;
And fleeting pleasure leaves me on the foyle:
Then I may turn a true Diogenes,
Snarle at the pleasures that I cannot tast,
Despise the gallantrys of Youth and Love,
And in my Tub grow nasty for my ease.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.l: Good morrow to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O my Friend!
The sight of thee, awakens the remembrance
Of all those pleasures we have pass'd together.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.l: I think the Roman Antony, in the rage
Of his luxurious Appetite, nay, when
He made the highest Sacrifice to Sense;
Ne'r rated Flesh and Blood as we have done:
Such Scenes of Wit! Such hours of Love and Wine!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O my Lesbino! Thou remember'st all!
Once at a Feast, when fair Panthea, crown'd
The Queen of Love, sate smiling on her Throne;
We humbly offer'd up our Vows; and strait
Beauty descended in a thousand Charms:
Selina's passion languish'd in her Eyes,
And thou wert caught;
Corrinna's Musick triumph'd o're the Sphere,
And over me: So all were happy made:
But then the jealous Goddess, from her seat
Flew to our Arms, and there was better pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.l: Yet this was censur'd!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Only by Clarinda,
Whose Vertue ne'r appear'd, but in her pride:
Whom I have since enjoy'd, with the dear thought,
Of leaving her to my Contempt and Scorn.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.l: Ah yes! there have been Days!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Have been! there are:
This day, to morrow, every day shall bawd
To our desires.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.l: The Regiments are marching,
And I must post to my Command to morrow.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: So suddenly! what Danger presses us?

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.l: Only a City-Plot: Curse on their Politick Noddles,
They've Brains enough to keep their Foreheads safe;
They cry the Soldier's surfeited with ease,
The tokens of foul Leachery appear—

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: On their own Wives and Daughters:

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.l: And out of Christian Charity to themselves,
And to prevent the growth of Cuckoldom,
At their expence they Physick the whole Camp,
And make a War, only to let us blood.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And thou hast not a vein, that thou wouldst spare
From old Rogero's Daughter: have I touch'd you?

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.l: Faith with wonder, to hear her mention'd here:
I thought her Birth, conceal'd her from all eyes.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: If among common pebbles, wee should find
A Diamond pave our way, 'twere quickly seen.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.l: You know her then?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And know her to be mine:
O I am the Columbus of that World,
And will grow rich in Beauty: pow'rful Gold
Has broke the Quarry up: And now Lesbino,
I have a Mother working in the Mine.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.l: What! make a Mother Bawd to her own Child?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O none so fit in Nature, the best knows
The constitution of her Daughters blood:
How high her pulses beat, remembers too
Which way the Devil danc'd, when she was young,
And there can play him now.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.l: My Lord! I am pleas'd the Lot is faln on you;
You'l keep the Sex in action: when we come
Hackt from the Feild, to find our Women right,
Under good Discipline, and Easiness,
Is all the Christian comfort of a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O! this is but the opening of the Scene
That shews my Triumph. Thou shalt know it all.
No answer of my Letter?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: None my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Attend without. Exit Servant.
Twas to Alphonso's house.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.l: Not to his Wife?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Suppose it were!

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.l: Do you expect an Answer?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I grant a Virgins modesty may blush,
And start at her own wishes: But a Wife,
A high-fed, wanton, understanding Wife,
That knows how Beauty in a Husbands arms,
Like treasure rusting in a Misers Chests,
Lies unenjoy'd, yet coveted by all:
For such a Wise secure on every hand,
From jealousie at home, and tongues abroad,
Youth in her veins, and Wishes in her heart,
That knows the price of opportunity:
For her to trifle out the hours of Love,
In coy denials, is beyond my Creed.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.l: But Sir, report speaks loudly of her virtue.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Why vertuous let her be to all the World,
To easie Husbands, and believing Fools:
For me I'm setled in my Faith: I've made
A study of the Sex, and found it frail:
The black, the brown, the fair, the old, the young,
Are earthly-minded all: There's not a she,
The coldest constitution of the Sex,
Nay, at the Altar, telling o're her Beads,
But some one rises on her heavenly thoughts,
That drives her down the wind of strong desire,
And makes her tast mortality agen. Enter Servant whispers Albertus and goes out.
Admit her.
This is the hinge of my designs:
Her Confidant; the bawdy Confessor,
That probes her Ladies Conscience to the quick,
To give it ease—she comes! you must withdraw.
What comfort? speak thou Messenger of Love!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Undone! undone! for ever! O my Lord!
I was born to be ruin'd in your service!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Hah! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Your Letter, by what accident I know not,
Is faln into my Lords hands.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Death and Hell! then all's discover'd.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Oh nothing but my falshood.

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.l: The Duke's name was subscrib'd.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Ay, you are not suspected: But the credit
Of my function's lost for ever. I have wept
And sworn my Innocence over, and over;
And all to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: That's hard indeed.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: He's raging mad, and has laid such a strict
Confinement on my poor Lady, so hardly us'd her,
That sure she'll never think of mankind more Alb. Shews a Purse.
Unless the thoughts of serving your Lordship, prevail
Upon my good Nature, to bring her about agen.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Here, thou hast won it fairly.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Our doors are all barr'd up, and none can find
Admittance but Lorenzo. 'Twas with difficulty
I stole to find you out, and let you know
I am not idle: leave the rest to me: I must away. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.l: I've heard it all. And now my Lord your thoughts upon the matter?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Faith: were it not for a charitable principle of my virtuous Friend there, in setting all things right agen: the power of my gold, and her own natural inclinations to the office, I should think my affairs were but in a melancholy condition.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.l: What do you resolve on?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: E'en to go, as the Devil in the Woman drives me,
For since the conquest that he made on Eve,
'T has been that Sexes business to deceive—
Juliana here! then I am impotent: Lesbino stay.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why do you start Albertus?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: This indeed
Was unexpected: I was us'd to see
You oftener: I should chide you: but retire,
I would not have you seen; Lesbino, there

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He has seen me here before.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ay Madam, but
We live in a censorious talking age,
And he is naturally fond of Scandal.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He is your friend.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: But it is hard to know
How far to trust a friend in these affairs;
Your reputation—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This is poor, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Nay then you'll not be answered. Ex. with Lesbino.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: To play the Woman right: now I should soon
Call Curses down from Heaven on his head,
Protest my wrongs, and vow to be reveng'd;
This were the furest way to please my Sex:
But why reveng'd? or how have I been wrong'd?
I knew him false before; the sad experience
Of other Women, warn'd me of my fate;
And yet I would not hold from venturing:
Had he refus'd me, then my wrongs were plain:
But I have met the softest dear returns,
That Love could make, or longing Maids desire.
If he has left me, 'tis his natures fault,
That cannot be confin'd.
O Clara! welcome.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Madam, I find my Lord has soon dispatch'd your business.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I have met the entertainment I expected here;
But Clara, must I lose him thus?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I have told you,
He loves my Lady: And he bribes me high
To prove his advocate in this affair;
But yet methinks I would do much for you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And thou shalt find I wonnot starve my cause:
I'll prove a grateful Client.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: As we walk;
We'll think upon the means.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Then let the wanderer rove,
So I enjoy him in his rounds of Love.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: She might have numbred out the Stars in Sin;
Fed her hot, lustful appetite with change
Of every high-fed, wanton fool in Florence;
Yet I have been happy: ignorantly blest,
Like a true marriage Tool. I might have sate
Contented, at the lower end o'th feast,
To welcome all, without a farther thought:
And when the Business of the day was over,
When all the company had danc'd her round;
At night I might have ta'ne her to my heart,
With praises on her Truth and Constancy,
And thanks to Heaven for such a vertuous Wife!

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Alphonso: hear me!

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: But to know my self a Monster! Death and Hell!
Children, and fools will have me in the wind,
And I shall stink of Cuckold to the World.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Come, come: you search too deep, and make your wound.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: O! I have nothing left me but thy friendship
To satisfie mankind, I once was thought
Above the reach of such a common Fate.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: You are above it still.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: By Heaven I should be:
For I'll appeal to reason; is it fit
This man thou hast honour'd with the name of friend,
Should fall so low, to be the common scorn
Of Pimps and Bawds?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Your thoughts are on the rack:
But recollect your reason to your aid,
And cast about, to find this treacherous slave
That has abus'd you; if I then forsake you,
May the severest vengeance of your fury
Fall here, and mark me with the Villains shame.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: O! think'st thou I am thus, without just cause?
Had my broad-mouth'd, sland'rous Villain said it,
I would have turn'd him outward to the Sun,
Display'd th' infected Fountain of his thoughts,
And stabb'd the venom'd lye down to his heart:
But when the Duke's own character confirms it!

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Friend, have a care how you pursue that thought;
There's danger in the way, therefore no more.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: And yet by Heaven! I cannot blame the Duke;
For the has beauty that may justifie
All actions, that are meant to compass her;
Oh! I am well acquainted with her pow'r:
I have devour'd the spirit of her Love,
Till drunk with joy, I reel'd to my undoing.
Her eyes have shot me with a thousand fires;
A thousand times, the little weeping loves,
That wanton'd in the liquid Crystal there,
Like April showers melting on my Cheeks,
Refresh'd my Veins into a wanton spring.
O she is more than I can speak or think,
The softest Bosom dear! The tenderest Wife!

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Yet you would part with her.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Not for the Wealth of Pluto, were she true:
But she is false, and all my comfort now
Must be to drive her from my thoughts for ever.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: For ever!

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Yes, among the follies of my life, I wou'd
Forget the Sex: I wou'd not call to mind
How I have sold the Charter of my Manhood,
To please the fondness of a Womans longing:
I would not count those tedious hours agen,
(Tho in my thoughts!) which I have sacrific'd
To the fantastick pride of that vain Sex.
But what I wou'd have bury'd to the World
Is the remembrance of that fatal hour,
In which I fondly ventur'd out my hopes;
My peace of mind, my honour, and my Love,
In the weak, Sinking Bottom of a Wife:
O sleep that thought, and I shall be at ease!

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: You speak as if there were no Woman true.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: I know not what I speak: but if my Wife,
If my Erminia's false, the Sex is damn'd;
I know it; and she was the last that fell.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Call old Rogero's Daughter to your mind,
To prove there may be vertue in that Sex,
Tho tempted by necessity, and want,
That Gold could not corrupt, nor pow'r betray.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: What poor! and honest! and a Woman too!
Does she still keep that point? then who can tell
But I may be abus'd.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: By Heaven you are!
Some Villain practises against your peace,
Whom time will best discover: For Erminia
So well I know the conduct of her life,
I'd stake my Soul upon her Innocence.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Is this thy thought?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: By Heaven my friend it is.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Wou'd I cou'd make it mine.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Go see her then.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: I dare not trust my Temper.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Come you shall,
I've given my word.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: To whom?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Your mourning Wife.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: You mock my misery.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I am your friend.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: But did Erminia make it her request?
Speak, cou'd she? O the suff'ring Innocence!
Thy words have darted hope into my soul
And comfort dawns upon me! O speak on!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Her soul in sadness, and her eyes in Tears,
Sighing she said! She fear'd her heart might break;
But she wou'd learn the vertue of a Wife,
And labour patiently to suffer all;
Then at my feet, in all the storm of Grief,
She begg'd me, as for life, to see her Lord;
And ever as she did repeat your name
Such floods of sorrow burst from her bright eyes,
I could not keep my manhood, but wept too.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: If thou wert mov'd my friend! oh what must I
Have been—had I been present at the view?
Such tenderness must have disarm'd my soul,
And thrown me for forgiveness at her feet:
But 'tis not yet too late.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Then you will see her?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Thy mournful Story has subdu'd my heart,
And I have not a thought that does oppose me.
Witness it Heaven! and Earth! and thou my friend,
I combated this Passion of my Love,
Stood this high Test of honour to my pow'r,
But am o'ercome: I am, I am a man,
And can no longer bear it. O Lorenzo!
My panting Heart beats to Erminia's brest,
Struggles and heaves, and fain would be at rest;
Weary'd with fears, and jealousies, wou'd come,
Thoughtless and free, to tast content at home;
From such a Friend, nor my Erminia's Love.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I Parted with Lorenzo on my promise,
To see my Wife, and yet I loyter here
In a perplexing maze of crowding doubts:
I'll think no more on't: Ha—Alberto here!—

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Alphonso! I have met you luckily.
I came to find you out.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I am glad my Lord
Your trouble's at an end, and I am found.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Our Master the great Duke—

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Sir, what of him?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Has sent me to you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O he honours me,
Too much of late, beyond a Subjects thanks:
What will this come to? aside.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Hearing that you have left the Court.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: For that
There's a necessity calls every man
Into his own concerns, and Business, Sir,
In spight of Fortune, will usurp sometimes.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Twas something sure of moment, unexpected,
Cou'd cause that haste, at which the Court admires.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Why Sir admire? is it a miracle
To find a Courtier honest, at his house
With his own Wife! 'tis hardly Treason this,
Nor would I have it an offence to any.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O! none at all: but yet the Duke that knows
Persons of your esteem, and quality
Make the full blaze of honour in his Court,
Would have you alwaies near him: therefore Sir,
To night he makes a publick entertainment,
Where you and your fair Lady are his Guests.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Sits the wind there! aside.
He over honours me, and I shall think
My self too poor, and thankless a return
For this high Grace: pray let his Highness know,
My Sword and Fortune wait upon his will.
But I am ill at measures, and must beg
To be excus'd.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Your Lady dances well.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Y'are in the right my Lord: she does indeed;
She sings well too: if I may be a Judg,
Who am her Husband, exquisitely well;
Yet who would think it?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Nay you, my Lord,
Are out at Miracles; and this indeed
Requires a Husbands faith: Yet you shall hear it;
My Wife (how prompted she can only tell!)
Tho bred up to the pleasures of the Court,
With all those entertaining qualities,
That men admire, and Women envy,
Young, as she is, now, when her blood might well
Employ her Beauty in its proper use;
Faints in the fury of her appetite:
And, (what I must confess I blush to own)
She foolishly affects a Huswives praise
Amongst her Maids, and spins her Youth away.
Is not this strange?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O most impossible!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: That I expected, and indeed I grant you.
This vulgar, wife-like vertue, huswifry,
In a young Lady, is scandalously old,
Quite out of fashion and must be forgotten.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: You cannot be in earnest?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O my Lord!
Marriage would mainly help your unbelief. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: As hanging cures the Tooth-ach; Go thy way
Old jealousie: tho I have fail'd in this:
Clara fights wary, and can never miss. Exit.

div.head: A SONG by an unknown hand.
div.l: POor, ill-instructed, wretched Woman-kind!
Decre'd by Fate,
Preposterously to Love and Hate;
Our feeble Mind.
Yields up the Keyes of our ill-guarded Treasure,
To Tyrant Man, whose arbitrary reign
Scarce gives us Will, or Power to complain:
Ʋs and our Passions they inchain;
The fleeting pleasure
Holds no proportion with the lasting Pain.
And thou the most ungrateful of thy Race,
Who hast my Honour, wouldst my name deface,
Cease thy pursuing,
To my undoing.
Since all the cruel Perjuries I prove,
Do but exalt the merit of my Love,
And whilst thy Falshood immortal proves to me,
My Love aspires to Immortality.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: My melancholy thoughts are all employ'd
On those hard-fated Maids, that are bought in,
By some poor circumstance of Interest,
To the eternal Slavery of life.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Ah! who that sees in you the marriage joys,
Will ever trust their Freedom with a Man?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: In me! I am most happy in content:
I love the hand that layes this load upon me,
And shall although it sink me to my Grave:
O Clara! this were wretchedness indeed;
This usage, were beyond the reach of patience,
From any, but Alphonso, him I love,
Him, whom my Heart hangs after for its peace.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: In him, 'Tis Tyranny to use you thus.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: O! I am run behind-hand with my Love:
I have not yet discounted for those Sums,
Those endless Sums of Joys; that made me happy:
And these are but the poor compounding tears;
The Scene of sorrow the bare interest.
Which I will pay, till he remits the debt,
And takes me to the comfort of his Bosom.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: He sends for me, invites me to the Court,
To bring my Wife to Court; now the great Duke
Appears himself, and claims me for his Cuckold.
What! bring my Wife to Court! Damnation! none
But I to bawd to my disgrace; sure something
Appears upon me, spiritless and poor,
That marks me for that Office, in his eye:
He durst not else have done it:—
I believe her honest yet:
Her Body not acquainted with the Sin,
But if her thoughts run foul, her mind's a Whore:
And the next oportunity compleats
My black dishonour.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Madam my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Mistris, you.
I guess your reverend function by your face.
Nay, here's money for you: An ounce of Gold for but a grain of truth:
Canst thou inform me of thy Ladies thoughts!
How they're employ'd! on whom? O tell me that,
And I will yet believe thou may'st live on
Some years in Sin, before th' art to be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Good Heaven defend, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Nay, then thou art a praying-Chamber-Bawd
And truth abhors thee. Foh! how she stinks o'th Office. thrusts her out.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: My Lord! my much lov'd Lord!
How has my ignorance betray'd my peace,
And rob'd me of your Love? Alass I own,
Freely confess the frailties of my Sex,
With all its forms and follies here before you:
Oh then if I have blindly stumbled on
A fault, in pity to my weakness, you My Lord, will pardon it.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Does the remembrance of any Sin Upbraid your thoughts?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: My Sins are infinite, As is the mercy of relenting Heaven.
But I defie my Memory, combin'd
With the severest malice of my Fate,
Since the first happy minute of our Loves,
To point me to a Crime against my Lord.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What! not in thought Erminia?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: No, indeed! Not even in thought, as I do hope for Heaven!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Then where's the need of pardon? You are justify'd:

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Alas! I do beseech you on my knees,
With streaming eyes, and a poor bleeding heart
Inform me: Let that Tempest on your Brow,
Fall on the wretched Head of lost Erminia;
But speak! O let my accusation come,
And tell what I have done to move you thus.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Damnation! done! Speak answer me! what, done!

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Alas! what means my Lord?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Have you done any thing? that thus your guilt betrays you to the question?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Indeed I know of nothing to offend you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O, were it come to that; did I but once
Conceive a slight suspition of the deed; It were not time for words—
Erminia, I believe y've done no fault.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Then I am happy in my Innocence.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: There's not a line in all that beauteous Face,
That promises the picture of a Whore;
By Heav'n! she should be honest to the Soul;
O! I could curse that first seducing Priest,
Who with false reasons triumph'd o'er the World,
And reconcil'd Mankind to Slavery:
Whilst he, and all that reverend, fatted Tribe,
Skill'd in the Arts of Luxury, and Ease,
Wisely refus'd the Doctrines that they taught,
And only damn'd the Layity to a Wife.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Did you not name your Wife?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I did Ermenia; And with a Curse upon the cunning Priest,
That conjur'd us together in a Yoak, that galls me now.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Wou'd I had never been, or never liv'd to hear you Curse me from you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No I will ever bless to my Grave.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Will you! then sure, oh sure, you cannot hate!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: By Heaven and Earth! I never can, Erminia!
No: by th' eternal Majesty that aws me,
I languish with the fondness of my Love,
Still doat, and fain would keep thee to my heart:
Oh! thou'rt the very fountain of my joyes,
The spirit of my peace, my spring of Life,
All that my wishes would, or Heaven can give:
Yet, oh eternal Torment to my Love!
We must, we must Erminia.—

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: What my Lord? O sure my heart informs me of my fate:
What must we?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: 'Tis Heaven alone can tell,
How fatally the secret struggles here!
With what impetuous force it beats my Breast;
And tears away my quiet in its way;
Therefore, it comes. O! we must part for ever:
I can no more. Farewell. she follows him.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: This, and all's well. Remember poor Erminia in her Grave. she swoons.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: She sinks, she's gone: Erminia! stay, my life!
O I conjure you by those thousand hours
Of softest joyes, that melted in thy arms;
And by those thousand years of Love to come,
I charge you stay.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Sure 'tis the voice of Love,
That summons me to life, and my Alphonso.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Look up, Erminia! see, I'm rooted here,
Fix'd to thy fate, and cannot live without thee.
There are ten thousand blessings yet behind,
Untasted by the palate of our Loves,
That wait to Crown our Dayes and Nights together.
And oh my heart can never think of Joy,
Nor move me one step onward to my peace,
Without the partner of my happiness.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Am I? Then sure we must not part?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O never. Forget the guilty thought, as I have done.
Thou something dearer to me than my Life!
Grow to my Heart, for ever fix thee here;
Till time, long Ages hence, shall call us down,
Old, and embracing, to one Grave together.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Then I am truly happy; Yet my Lord,
(Forgive the folly of a Womans fears)
If your late Coldness ever shou'd return,
No wretchedness on Earth could equal mine.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Drive me not back, upon my memory,
But take me to thy Arms, and I will lose
All thoughts, but of almighty Love and thee.
Thus Tempest-beaten voyagers at last
(Tost by the fury of the angry Main:)
Secure and safe are in the Harbour cast,
And never, never venture out again.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: I've dropt my Husband in the crowd, and this is the
Walk, my Lord Alberto promis'd to meet me in:
Come hither Angelline! hold up thy head Child! ah! thy
Mothers own Twincle! well, fifteen
Must be provided for, I see that.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I do not understand you.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: No matter for that, I understand enough in this point
For us both, Child: if you have but the Grace to be rul'd?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I hope I have ever been obedient.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Ay. 'Twill be the better for you: say your Prayers duely,
And take your Mothers advice along with you,
And you may come to keep your Coach one day.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Alas! I am contented with my poor Condition,
And would not, if I might, be what you say;
And see my good old Father go on foot.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: No Angelline, He and I, and all of us shall ride, if you
Will be instructed to raise us. You know the Lord Alberto?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Him, that you shew'd me walking with the Duke.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Ay there's a man for you: to my certain knowledg
He's directly in Love with thee.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: So indeed the Lord Lorenzo tells me, he loves me;
And tho I am more inclin'd to credit him,
Yet I am far from thinking of it true.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Come, you shall love both.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: That's impossible! both cannot marry me.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Marry you, no matter for that: but both may serve
Your turn a great deal better, another way:
Come Angelline. Thy Father's poor, thy Beauty's
Thy portion, and manage it to the best advantage.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Poor as I am, I scorn to be a Whore.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Bless me! how can you expect to thrive with such
Abominable, ungodly words in your mouth, Child?
A Whore, fy, fy don't think of the indecent thing,
But as I was saying, there will be beauty enough at
Five and Twenty, to throw away upon a Husband;
Then if you should chance to tarnish, or grow rusty in the
Wearing, (as Beauty alass! is but a flower, and flowers
Will fade.) 'tis but the Matrimony dip at last, and you
Appear agen as fresh, with as glossy a Complexion, as
You had never been blown on, and no harm done—I think
I see him coming—
Oh! 'Tis my unseasonable Husband agen, that out of a starving principle of
Honesty, will neither stir himself, nor suffer me to labour in the lawful Occupation
of a Mother for the advantage of a poor Child. weeps.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Oh! have I found you! 'Tis very well—A pox o' these
Hot Countries. There's no taking a mouthful of Air,
Without the venture of being choak'd with the flies:
How they swarm in every walk! Coxcombs of every size,
And Nation! from the impertinence of the French,
Down to the leaden figure of a Dutchman.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Who have we here?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: The very Picture of folly in leading-strings! now by his
Countenance I should guess there has not been an ounce of
Brains in the Family, since his Fathers great Grandfather
Mortgag'd his, to the purchasing a Title.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Of what Sir? a Fool! does that bear such a value in
The World?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: O Child! none but our swinging Estates can come up
To the price on't: our Lords buy by the whole piece,
So that a poor man can hardly come in
For a remnant of that Commodity.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Methinks I should not covet to forestal their Markets.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Ah. Thy Fathers own Daughter to a hair! nay, thou hast a tang of thy Mother in thee too, I'll say that for thee Angelline! Thou follow'st good Example: she might have been a Lady, as she says: But no matter for that; she was wiser as I take it: For I' gad I was a Swinger in those Days: Let me— I cou'd have done — I do'nt know what I could have done.—But 'tis past time a day with me now: come, let's home, or these Vermin will be biting.

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.p: Well, well. Let me alone I warrant you I break her Heart Boys: But heark you Poet! you'll stand by me and prompt upon occasion: While you with your Whiskers terrify my Mistris into silence and attention.

div.stage: Squire advances between his Poet and Bully.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: The thing comes towards us.

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.p: Now— will I be Alexander the Great; and with thy right hand, my Poets Brains, and my own Estate, beat down the fortifications of these Amazons, and ravish to the end of the Chapter.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Bear up Sir.

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.p: Soft, and fair: A General should not be hot-headed you know: Poet, where are you?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Now Sir, —Bright as &c. prompting.

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.p:
Ay, ay:
Bright as the Virgin Tresses of the Day,
When Neptune scours the Sun-beams from the Sea.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: What does he mean Sir?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: —My Eyes, &c. prompting agen.

q.l: —My Eyes are scoarcht by your illustrious Face;

l.hi: Like dry'd Tobacco by a burning-Glass.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: There's Poetry for you.

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.p: Ay, there's Poetry for you.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Sir, I am poor enough to pretend Acquaintance to the Muses; but I confess I do'nt understand you. Therefore without your Tresses, Sun-beams, and your Neptunes, I ask you what you would have?

sp.speaker: Bully.
sp.p: Have Sir?

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.p: Have Sir?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Ay, have Sir!

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.l: Prithee Bully Whiskers tell him you—
I am not much for fighting. walks off

sp.speaker: Bully.
sp.p: Why! may be nothing Sir. What then Sir?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Why then I am satisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.p: Why look you there. I knew he was a civil honest Fellow.

sp.speaker: Bully.
sp.p: Pox, he knows his men.

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.p: Hark thee old Lad. I have a great mind to be better acquainted with thee. Prithee now, if a man may be so bold; What a Pox art thou?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: What am I! why I am nothing, have nothing, care for nothing, nor depend on nothing.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: He comes of a very Ancient Family.

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.p: Nothing say'st thou? why then I gad I'll have the honour of thy Creation: But first here's mony for thee: Now thou art Pimp-master in ord'nary to my Family, from this day forward; and begin thy Office upon that same little Gipsie there.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Oh I am proud that I have a Daughter for you; but I intend to give you the first fruits of my service gratis. And return your Gold to these Rascals, that deserve it for keeping you company. And this to your Worship. kicks him.

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.p: Nay if you are thereabouts, your Servant!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: As you like me, reward me!

sp.speaker: Bully.
sp.p: Come away! Sir, 'tis a poor old mad fellow, and is not worth your anger; and Faith it goes against my Conscience to murder him, when he has bid so high for my Friendship. Else by the threshold of Mahomets Temple.—

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Let him alone, I am big with Madrigal and will prostitute his Daughter to a Tinker in my next Lampoon.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: This will elevate your Imagination Draws and scours 'em off.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Rogero! what my old Bully of Sixty five.
Levying War with thy Regiments of years about thee! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: The matter, my Lord! why every thing's the matter.

The Coxcomb was in the matter in provoking me; and I was in the matter for beating the Coxcomb about the matter, that in the whole matter it is not a farthing matter, whether there had been any matter or no.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Very well: but prithee what pretty Creature is that there?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Where Sir? who Sir? my Wife Sir?
What have you to say to my Wife Sir?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: More than you imagin. aside.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Nothing, nothing, I man!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Nothing my Lord! why let me tell you my Lord, She has been—

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ay, and is still Rogero, a good old Geneva print for you that use Spectacles:
You that use spectacles: But I wear my own
Eyes, and would fain know
Who this lovely young thing is?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Lovely did you say! I'gad and you are i'th right on't:
There's a Wench for you.
A Mistris for an Emperour, by Jupiter! my own picture
To a Hair! A Rogue, there's a shape, there's a face,
Then her Eyes and Lips; see how they blubb and pout, and
Twitter and swell at you!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Rogero! I'll make bold, and tast your fruit. kisses Ang.

div.stage: Rogero going between Alberto and Angelline.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: So much for Civility: And now my Lord, I am sorry for't,
But this same idle Girl of mine, this same, what you will,
This Chit, this any thing, has suck'd such a foolish principle
From her Mother, I am asham'd on't.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Prithee Rogero; what is't?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Why I am sorry for't, but I vow to gad she is not for your turn.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Only out of stark Love, and kindness, that a Person of your
Quality should lose his labour, for to my certain
Knowledg, she is most damnably honest;
Come away Angelline. Come away Child.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I do not understand thee.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Nor do I intend to explain at present: but my Lord
You'll pardon me. I know nothing of the matter;
My Wife must answer it, it lies at her door. Ex. Rog. and Ang.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: He knows nothing of my design:

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: 'Tis only his humour.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Pox on him! how came he here to disturb us?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: He met us, at Chappel.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Nay, if our Saints prove no better friends to the intreagues
Of this World, we shall foon fall off the zeal of
Our devotion to them.
But tell me, when shall be the happy hour?
The fragrant infancy of opening flowers,
Flow'd to my senses in that melting kiss:
O! I am wild, impatient as desire,
To force the blushing Beauty to my Bosome,
And there dissolve it to the Balm of Love,
Speak, tell me, when! oh when?

sp.speaker: Mo
sp.l: Alas, my Lord! you think I have done nothing for you!
Have not I? When Nature, Conscience,—

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I know thou hast: nay nay, here's the best Recipe for
A troublesom Conscience in Christendom gives a Purse.
Probatum est. I warrant it good, Mother.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Well: I am asham'd of your Bounty; but you are so
Winning a Person, you might ha' commanded me without
A Reward. But to morrow my Lord, you shall see her:
If she should prove frail. But no matter for that,
You are a vertuous person, and will scorn to take
The advantage of her weakness.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Not in the least, do not doubt me. Ex. Mother.
So, this Conquest's sure; now for Alphonso's Wife,
That suffering Martyr to a wedded Life;
If her false vertue be not to be sold,
Farewel our surest Panders, power and gold. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Come, come! I know you love him: Alberto is
A very Master in the Arts of Love:
Practis'd in all the soft bewitching wayes,
That find the weakness of a Womans heart;
Therefore without a blush you may confess it.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I would hide something from you willingly.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Tell me, is there not something in your heart pleads strongly for him?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: If something from without
Did not plead more, his cause were desperate.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Indeed I hear your Mother favours him.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Would I could say, 'twere false.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You came to meet him here.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: My Mother I believe had so design'd:
For as we came from Chappel with my Father,
She watcht her time, and lost him in the Crowd.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Does he allow it?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: No; he forewarns me of him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And be advis'd: fly from his Charms betimes,
There is no other safety: if you think
To stand, and guard the passes to your heart;
You are undone: Oh! I have heard him talk,
Like the first Child of Love, when every word
Spoke in his eyes, and wept to be believed,
And all to ruine me: had I more time
To tell my story out, 'twould move your pity:
But yonder comes your Father!
I'll see you suddenly agen: Farewel. Exit Juliana.

div.stage: Enter Lorenzo and Rogero to Angelline.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Rogero, I am well acquainted with thy worth:
Have studyed thee; observ'd thee in our Wars,
Where the hard chance of Fortune, threw thy Lot
Among the meanest of our Souldiery;
Unheeded, friendless, destitute of all;
Till that blunt spirit of thy honesty,
And forwardness to all attempts of honour,
Forc'd back thy fate, and made thy vertue known.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Yes. I have been a Souldier; and have been rewarded too:
Had promises for pay.
And starv'd for the honour of my profession.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Well: all shall be amended; come to Court
And but apply thy self to our great Duke,
And thou shalt find a Prince, whose vertue will
Redeem thee from the smart of poverty;
Reward thy merits with an open hand,
And nurse thy wanting age with ease, and plenty.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: My Lord! you know me: And I know my self; you bid
God bless the Duke, I cry Amen; with all my heart; so far
We're right: But here I leave you; not one step further, not an Inch my Lord
sp.p: I am not for the Court, not I my Lord; there's a ruggedness in my nature will not let me sell the freedom of my Mind, to feed my body: No, when I see a Fool, I must laugh at him; not sooth him in his vanity, nor tickle him,-till he wheeze, and give me an advantage of creeping to his pocket.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: But thy family, Rogero.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Ay, my Daughter here: why y'are in the right on't agen, well I confess
sp.p: I should be glad my Angelline were provided for; But I can neither pimp, flatter or lye for a portion for her.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Nor shalt thou need it: here, Rogero, cherish
Thy Daughters vertuous thoughts, nor let
Her wants betray her to Dishonor.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: My Lord: You should be honest.
But the honesty of this purse is no better than it
Should be: why, how many reverend Matrons has this
Corrupted into Bawds; 'Tis as sure a Damnation to a
Maiden-head, as fifteen, wit and a good face: But
Tempter, I defie thee; and tho it is reasonable I
Should be a Rogue for this; I'd have you to know I scorn the Office.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Away, away, do not suspect my friendship:
On all occasions use me, as thy purse;
That shall be open to thee, depend upon me,
And leave thy Daughters fortune to my care.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Angelline! dost hear that Child! Th' art made for ever.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Rogero! that Alberto, whom you spoke of
Runs in my thoughts: dost hear me; watch him close.
Observe him well: his favour with the Duke,
Passes those Actions currant to the world,
Which in an other man, were foul and monstrous:
Therefore beware of him! no more; farewel.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: My Lord! Your servant: But as I was saying, he has
The Christian Liberty of the Common to ramble in
As much as he pleases, and welcome: But if he be for
Leaping into inclosures: If he come to pasture in
My Ground; at his peril, at his peril, by Jupiter;
That's all, that's all: Your Servant my Lord, your Servant. Exit cum Angelline.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: She's gone, and all my thoughts are up in Arms,
Like wanton Citizens in Luxury,
Thronging in factious Parties, to their cause,
Resolv'd and headlong for their Liberties,
Before they know a danger: I am not
Of that soft temper, that the eye of Beauty
Can melt me from the Image of a Man,
Into the fondness of a Womans fool:
Yet if I am fated to a Marriage life,
My happiness were pure in Angelline;
In whom the infancy of Innocence,
In blushing vertue triumphs o'er agen,
But then the World! Why let the babling World
Report it as they please. Let Interest wed
The drudgery of a vexatious Bed;
Dayes without peace, and Nights without desire,
Still toil, and sweat away their youth for hire.
Whilst safe in Innocence, and Truth; I taste
The sweets of Love, fresh running to the last.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: TIS late, and I alone: th' hard travell'd Sun
Now wantons in the Bosom of the Sea,
Whilst amorous Clouds steal nearer to the Earth,
And melt themselves away upon the flow'rs:
The Beasts in Companies to Coverts run;
And all the feather'd Kind, upon the wing,
Pair to the Groves, and dream the night away.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Then, why art thou the loyterer of Love?
Why when Erminia's Arms are opened wide,
Expecting to embrace thee to thy rest;
Why then does my Alphonso chuse to wander
The melancholy maze of Darkness here?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O thou too justly dost present my Crime!
I own I am to blame, to call thee forth
Into the rawness of a midnight Air,
At this dark hour; But! O, forbear to think
'Twas from my choice, that I have staid thus long;
'Twas a rude thought, that wou'd not bo deny'd;
Indeed no more: prithee to bed, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Alas! There is no rest for me without thee!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O my Hearts comfort! yet a minute longer,
And I'll discharge my Soul of all its load;
Come trembling with my strong desires upon me,
To thy expecting arms, till thou confess
I've made amends for all the faults of Love.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: I will doubt your Truth! farewel my Lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Good night, my Love: O may the softest arm
Of downy slumbers rock thee to repose.
Lull all thy senses fast: And may no thought
(To interrupt the quiet of thy Bed)
(In the loose Revel of a Dream) present
Those Images, that keep me waking here.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Who's there? Alphonso?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ha! who calls?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Thy Friend.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Lorenzo! alwayes welcome to my Heart:
But now thou com'st, as if my Fate design'd
My Happiness should all depend on thee.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: 'Tis late! my friend, how fares thy vertuous Wife?

sp.speaker: Alph
sp.l: Well, very well: just parted hence, and now
Preparingg for her Bed.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Tomorrow we shall meet:
I have an idle thought to satisfie
And then to rest: Good night Alphonso.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Friend, am I to be a stranger to that thought?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Thou hast my Soul: But now Erminia stays;
Thy soft desiring Wife expects thy coming:
Busie in thought, and hasty for the hour,
She turns and sighs, and wishes; counts the Clock,
And every minute drags a heavy pace,
Till thou appear, the Champion of thy Bed,
Arm'd at all points, and eager for the charge,
That calls her to the Combat of thy Love.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No: not to night, Lorenzo.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Not to night!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No Friend: my thoughts are strangers to repose;
I'll not to bed.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Alphonso have a care:
And physick not thy health to a Disease,
If once the foul infection of a doubt,
But mingle with the current of thy thoughts;
The subtle poison seizes on the Heart,
Corrupts the very fountain of thy peace,
And then the minutes of the Damn'd are thine.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Lorenzo! no; I hope my Fate intends me
To nobler purposes. Yet.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: The Letter—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I must be satisfy'd of that!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You may.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: By Heaven I will.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Time must discover it.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O! may I be that hateful thing, I scorn!
The common, ridden Cuckold of the Town;
Stag'd to the crowd on publick Theatres,
Nay, balleted about the streets in rhime,
When for a wanton itching in my blood,
I gratifie a craving appetite;
And let the just resentment of a wrong,
Expect to morrow for a cool revenge.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I have a Sword, that wonnot be behind
In any task of Honour, for my friend:
Command me freely.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: 'Tis out come to that.
But thus Lorenzo, I accept thy Love!
Go to my Wife, tell her some discontents
Have forc'd me out to travel.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: How! Alphonso?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Observe me out, not that I doubt Erminia;
But when my absence is by all believ'd;
Conceal'd in private here, I soon shall find
My vigorous Lover bolting at my Wife;
And I may know to thank him for the Office.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: It has a Face indeed: Erminia too,
May bear a part in this.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Lorenzo, no.
Much may be gathered from her management,
In my supposed absence, that may serve,
Thro' the succeeding changes of my life,
To fix my temper to the point of vertue.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Where shall we meet?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I cannot wander far.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: This is the door. Farewel. goes in.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: So, now my Heart
Be still, beat even measures in my Breast,
That when the hour of Fate shall summon me
The fury of my firm collected force
May strike for Honour in a brave revenge.
Hark, 'tis the tread of Servants coming this way:
I would not be discovered. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Madam, This office that I venture on, in your service
Is but an ungenerous return for Alberto's bounty!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis the only way you have left you, Clara.
Your Lady has disappointed you: and as I take it,
Your Credit's engaged for the payment of a Sum to night,
Which I must either lay down,
Or you suffer in your trading hereafter.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Nay, I am easily perswaded; and, upon second thoughts,
Imagin there may be less danger, and more Conscience,
In this design, than my first undertaking.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O! a great deal more, Clara: for so you injure no body:
Your Lord will be no Cuckold, your Lady miss nothing, that
Ever she had, and I shall have but my own.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: True, Madam, But how shall I be just to him?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That I'll tell you too!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: He has paid for my Lady.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And he shall have her, or any Lady at the same rate.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How Madam! how? That Art were an Estate.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis but providing me a dark room, with a little of thy
Direction; and the Strength of his own imagination
Will carry on the Cheat.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: But if he shou'd discover!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why let him make the best of the discovery;
He'll find me a Woman, Clara.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Truly Madam, I begin to submit to your Arguments;
I believe this Project may take.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It has been succesful in England already: where intreagues
Are carried on with less management, than the Italian
Air will allow of.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Well, I never knew the good of a strong Imagination before.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis the best comfort, I fear, of a matrimonial Amour, Clara:
But when do you expect Alberto?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Tis near the time: Let's in and prepare to receive him.

div.head: A SONG made by Colonel Sackvile.

lg.l: O Why did e'er my thoughts aspire
To wish for that, no Crown can buy!
'Tis Sacrilege, but to desire
What she in honour will deny.
As Indians do the Eastern skies,
I at a distance must adore
The brighter Glories of her eyes;
And never dare pretend to more.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Well! were there nothing more in an intreague, than barely
The enjoyment, the unconscionable expence of the pleasure
Would take off our appetite to the Sin; and the Devil would
Soon fail of his correspondence with the World,
Unless the prizes of his Commodities fell, that honest
Fellows might be damnd'd at easier rates.
Where am I? Hold! O 'tis Alphonso's House.
And this the very hour, that Clara promis'd,
To meet me at, with all her Womans Arts,
And joyn in the dear Scene of Cuckoldom.
The door opens, I will observe at distance.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: My Lord gone in discontent to travel! and my poor
Lady left in distress here behind him; Let me see,
There are comfortable applications to be made out
Of these Doctrines. And if she has not the discretion
To turn 'em to their right uses; I that am wiser,
Am oblig'd in conscience to provide for the family.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And 'tis a charitable, Christian-like principle in thee, Clara.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: My Lord Alberto!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The same, I am punctual you see.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: And that's an extraordinary vertue in a young Lover,
And ought to be encourag'd in an Age, when poor
Women are us'd, just like your Trees; Husbanded only
Out of a vanity of having the first ripe fruit,
Without the desire of tasting of 'em your selves.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: No faith. I am for enjoying the fruits of my labour
Clara: Besides I have a vigorous young, craving
Appetite; (with a digestion above the fear of Crudities
These Forty years) that must be satisfy'd at home,
Before I think of being bountiful to my Neighbours,
But tell me! Alphonso gone to travel. Ha!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Most seasonably my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Then Love and Fortune for me: lead on Clara.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What do you mean!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O honestly I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: But consider my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I do Clara.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: My Ladies vertue!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And my secrecy: there's vertue for her vertue: nay, if you
Go to that, mine is a Cardinal vertue among the Ladies,
And ought to be respected in any Court in Christiandom,
Where the Love, as well as Religion is Catholick.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: But my Lord, you know decency requires—

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And I'll do't as decently as she,
Or any Lady can, in reason require.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: To morrow may prove more favourable to you;
My Lady has but just heard the news, and her thoughts
To night will run on my Lords unkindness.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Therefore it shall be to night: O! 'tis the natural constitution
Of Womankind, upon the first suspicion of their Lovers inconstancy,
To club with the next chance-comer for a revenge.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: So that who ever fasts,
The sweetest meats are prudently ordered to our own Table.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The Policy is true Machiavil, i'faith, on your sides;
And now for a stronger Testimony of this within.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: O hold, you ruine all else, I'le in before, dispose all things to the •• proper places, and return in an instant, for scandal must be avoided.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And 'tis but reasonable; for reputation is the fairest Face
Of Virtue, and will soonest cheat the World;
This brings the Physician his Patients, and the Lawyer his
Clyents; and though one destroy your Body, and t'other your
Estate: Opinion justifies their Knavery, and secures
Their Functions from Poverty and contempt.
Clara stayes long—Pox! I'm impatient—I'le 'een enter,
And do my Errand my self. [Exit.]

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: 'Twas here I left Alphonso: I know not why:
Some unseen Power directs my steps this way:
Would I could find the truth of what I fear:
He is abus'd: And he's so near my heart,
That when I think upon his injuries,
A just resentment arms within my Breast,
As if my better self were wrong'd in him.
I'le take another turn to find him yet.— Goes out and returns.
Perhaps I staid too long, and he is gone
To wait me at my House,—It must be so.—

div.stage: Enter Clara and Alberto at the door.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: 'Tis hard to leave my happiness so soon.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: There may be danger in a longer stay.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I must be satisfy'd, you say.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Ha! a Mans voice from Alphonso's House!
The door too open! There may be more in this;
A midnight Thief, or Murderer.—I'le venture
To secure him.
So brisk! have at you Sir. They justle and draw, as they are clos'd Clara enters with a Light, and Exit:

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ha! Lorenzo: 'Twas lucky that
This business grew not up to cutting Throats.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: My Lord! you are the Master of your thoughts,
They can inform you best.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Of what Lorenzo?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Whether you do deserve that Fate, or no?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: You dare not think I do.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: You know I dare
All honest things: But you, my Lord! are touch't. [Exit.]

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Y' are indispos'd, I'le leave you Sir.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Farewell.—
It must be so, else why alone? Why here
Alone? And at this Midnight hour? When none
But desperate Wretches wandring to their Fates,
Venture abroad, uncall'd. But then Erminia!
Damn her, she sins beyond a Curse! and Hell,
All Hell must do her Justice. Not allow
A minute for the Changing of the Scene.
She Wept! By Heaven I saw her faithless Tears,
And thought I saw Alphonso in her eyes,
Then, in that Minute, when the Devil and Lust
Where Bawding for Alberto in her Heart!
Oh Woman! Woman!
Dear Damn'd deceitful Sex! 'Tis my own fault,
If after this, I fall into thy Snare.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Lorenzo! Welcome as the hopes of Peace,
Thy presence brings to my divided Soul!
O take me to thy Armes and let me hide
These Guilty blushes, that at sight of thee
Start, and confess the weakness of thy friend.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What weakness! Speak Alphonso.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Woud'st thou think it?
Since last we parted, I have wandred on
Through the dark journies of the desart Night;
My ridden thoughts hagg'd with oppressing fears,
That sunk my Spirits to the depth of Hell:
And ever as I went, Erminia stood,
Like a tormenting Conscience in my way.
To keep me waking to the sence of pain.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: 'Tis scarce an hour since we parted.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Oh! The wretched count by years: By Heaven, my Friend,
Were I to live those minutes o're agen,
The horrors that attend on waking guilt
Would seize upon my thoughts, and hurry 'em
Into the wildness of a mad Despair.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Despair, and Guilt and Horror. These are fit
Companions for the Damn'd: The Murderer,
In his last Death-bed Agonies, hears such sounds,
To summon him to everlasting Woe:
My Friend knows no such Crimes.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Lorenzo! Oh Erminia!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Instruct my weakness here,
How to begin, what I shall say to move her,
How to confess my self enough her slave.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You rave Alphonso.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Oh to thee I do!
But didst thou know what 'tis to bear about thee
A heart subdu'd, devoted to desires,
Which, fierce as the first appetite of Youth,
Drive violently to thee Goal of Love:
That would inform thee better.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: I cannot guess what you resolve on?

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: On my Happiness.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.l: Like a Wastful Prodigal,
I have long spent in folly, from my store;
But there is yet behind a large Estate;
The promise of Eternal joyes to come,
In my Erminia's Armes, where I will run
And Love in quiet all my Life away.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: 'Tis well resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: My Heart must bear me Witness
With what unwillingness I entertain'd
Those fears that shap'd these Monsters in my Soul;
Then judge me all the World, and thou my Friend,
With what a start, and Eagerness of Joy,
I meet that peace, that ministers a Cure.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You mean Erminia!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I do: My Wife!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Is there such healing Virtue in a Wife?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Oh she's the kind Physician of my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Nay then I ask your Patdon: Faith Alphonso,
I thought a Wife, like other Remedies,
By often application might grow stale,
And be a worthless drugg upon our hands.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Lorenzo, Thou art alter'd in thy thoughts.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Men are not still the same: Our Appetites
Are various, and inconstant as the Moon
That never Shines with the same Face agen;
'Tis Nature's Curse never to be resolv'd;
Busy to Day, in the pursuit of what
To Morrows elder judgment may despise.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: These are the mouldy Morals of the Dead.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: That speak the living plain: Art thou the same?
Art thou not alter'd from what last I saw thee?
The Hero strutting in thy pageant pride:
Swell'd with thy wrongs, and bursting with resentment?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Go, you would yet be more her slave.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: What mean these words?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Your Tongue can best explain
The Dictates of your heart: But now you said
You wish'd you knew to be enough her slave,
I think 'twas so.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: It was by Heav'n!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And Faith I thought a Husband needed not that Prayer.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Y' are merry friend!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Would thou would'st be so too!
And learn to think no farther of the Sex
Than for thy ease and pleasure.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Still in Riddles!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: To Morrow will unfold 'em: I must leave you,
But friend, the Night's far spent, Erminia too
Can live till Morn without you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Sayst thou Friend?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: To Night you must not see her?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Not see her?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Lorenzo, There is something in thy thoughts
Thou dar'st not trust me with—I hope she's honest.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O doubtless, honest.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: How did she bear thy Message?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Faith, Alphonso,
If I may count her sorrow by her Tears,
She very hardly bore it: For she wept,
Had not all Hell been kindled in her heart, Aside.
Enough to have cool'd the Burning Devil there!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Then I am satisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Agen!
Where would'st thou drive my doubts? If thou woud'st have
Me think thee still the same, my Friend, and Honest,
Inform me of thy thoughts?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Then thou art Wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: That's the Disease! and know
The Poisonous Scorpion that has made the Wound,
Has vertue in its Blood to work a Cure:
The Man, my Friend, the Villain that hath done it!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: There I must be Excus'd!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Not tell me?
The Honour of thy Friend engag'd! and thou
Conceal the Villain from a just Revenge?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Not now! another time.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: This prostituted outside-art may pass
Upon the World, where Interest is a Friendship,
But is despis'd, and scorn'd by nobler Souls.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You know me better; and I thought Alphonso
My virtue had been try'd, and found sufficient
To justify our Honours to the World;
You might have trusted me with yours till Morn:
To Morrow we shall meet on better term; Farewell.— [Exit.]

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I was too blame: I know him honest:
And know his thoughts are labouring for my Peace!
Yet why he should conceal the Villains Name
Confounds me? Hold! if it should prove the Duke!
Confusion! All my spirits take the Alarm!
Forward to do me noble justice there.
Tis so — I know it now—Lorenzo too,
Divided in his thoughts, betwixt his Friend,
And Master, comes half-hearted to my Cause,
Till Fame report my Vengeance to the World.
Who's there?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Who's there Sir? why may be I am here Sir! may be
I am not here! what's that to any man, Sir?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Nothing at all, Friend.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Here's a Rogue for you now, a fine embroider'd Rogue!
That would scrape acquaintance for fear of a beating.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: This Fellow may be of use.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Friend, you say, y' are very welcome Sir, but as I take it,
I never saw you in my life before.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Then down with it for a secret.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: That an old man may be wiser than his beard: mum, not a word of this, as you hope for instruction.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: I'll keep your Council.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Wilt thou my old Lad! Thou shalt never wear
Spectacles more then: Hast thou heard no news of late?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: No tidings of thy Wits! God help thee.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Why then I'll tell thee, the Duke—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: What of him?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Why who would think it now?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Think! what!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: That when the Devil's in the head; the Breeches shou'd be honest.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: What's this to the Duke?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Excuse me there: There's a method in State Affairs, which we Politicians amble in to the end of our discourse, now, Sir, if you will mortifie the vehemence of your desire, with the phlegm of your discretion, and attend with patience, much may be done, and so I may come in order to what relates to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Very well, very well.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: But Sir, 'twill not be very well! when y'have heard it all.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Pray Sir, go on.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: You know the Duke.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: I think I have some reason.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: You know him well.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Not well enough to lye with him.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: 'Tis enough you know him.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Know him! ah God help thee, and the quantity of thy Brains, by thy impertinent Catechism.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Why then old True penny the Duke is now most violently in labour.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: In labour! Alas, I am in pain for thee.

sp.speaker: Alhh.
sp.l: And by an act of State, this very day
We are oblig'd, as all good Subjects ought,
To bring by turns our Wives and Daughters in
As the best means of bringing him to bed.
How the poor Fools, I warrant you, will strive who first shall lay him.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: How, my Daughter to be a Midwife at fifteen! God sa' me she is not come to the Criss-cross-row of her profession yet.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Hast thou a Daughter? home, quickly home then: lock up thy doors.
Let her not see the day: Let her not draw the open
Air: for if there be a pore unbarr'd about her,
The bawdy Devil will get in, and then, Good morrow Grandfather.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Gad, and it may be so, who can tell, ha! come Sir, 'tis late
If you'll along with me, you'll find a hearty welcome, and poor fare.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I thank you Sir, I'll follow you: This disguise
Of Folly may conceal me for a night,
And my revenge to morrow sets me right.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Your Lady not a bed?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Alas in tears,
She has spent the night, remov'd from comfort here, and from all eyes. She mourns the hours away.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: My visit may disturb her more.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: She says you are always welcome.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: She rises: I will venture on, and spare
Your farther service. Exit Clara.
How is it with you, Madam? to Ermin.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: As with one,
Who, wandring over a wide, barren waste,
Views the last circles of the sinking Sun,
Then gazing round, quite destitute of hope,
Forsaken and forlorn, sits sighing down,
To mix with night, and entertain despair:
You are that friendly Traveller, whom chance
Has this way brought, to guide me safely home;
O lend some charitable succour to me,
And let me stray no farther from my joyes!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: There's such an Angel innocence appears,
And pleads her cause i'th front of all her Crimes;
That if I look upon her, I must think
That 'tis impossible she should be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: The hand of Heaven has reacht my Crimes and why!
Oh why shou'd I complain? Yet I must own,
When I reflect upon Alphonso's loss!
Oh when I think on that, my poor heart swells,
Beats in my breast, and rises at its wrongs,
Disputes the Justice of the Courts above,
And thinks my punishment out weighs my Crimes.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: She'll talk me from the credit of my sense, if she goes on!

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Oh had wife Heav'n design'd
To prove my vertue this way: I had stood
Firm as the Foot of Resolution;
And weary'd out the Tryal of a Saint!
Afflictions of all kinds, the loss of Friends,
The shame of Poverty, and the hand of Want,
Diseases, Infamy; all, all together
Drive me far off the Comforts of this World;
But my Alphonso! Oh I cannot think
Of life without him.— Heaven has made us one,
Nor shall the malice of our Fate divide us.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: It was Alberto, for I was awake:
Death! I'le believe my Eyes in spight of Hell.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Lorenzo; you, nay you and Heaven must do
A Justice here, and witness to my truth.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What does she drive at now?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: How I have ever liv'd, and always will,
(Tho banisht from his sight, and bed for ever)
His truly loving and obedient Wife.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Indeed a most obedient, loving Wife!

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Alass! Lorenzo! I have lost in him
All that this World calls happy, and may peace
Be still a stranger to my thoughts, if I
Can guess a Cause.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Indeed! Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Thus in this awful posture, I invoke
Heaven, Earth and Men to evidence my Truth:
May Comfort never find me, if my heart
E're sent a Wish to any other man:
If when my Eyes have wander'd, they have fixt
On any other Object of Desire.
Then why? Oh why am I thus hardly us'd?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: In tears! away! send sorrow to the Grave:
Let the stale, dry bon'd Matron wish and weep
Her wrinkles full, at the sad memory
Of those dear joys, that never must return:
Oh think on that; There is the wretchedness
That sadly sighs, Youth is not always ours.
That Beauty that invites all Eyes, and now
Charms every Heart, in favour of your Cause,
(When time shall sink his surrows on your Cheeks)
Will pass neglected; Therefore be advis'd,
And do not lavish out those Charms in Tears,
That are a Debt to Love.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Alass! my Charms
Are useless now: The power that first made
And Conjur'd these faint Beauties into Charms,
Withdraws his Influence; my lov'd Alphonso—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: No more of Him.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: No more of my Alphonso!
Is he not mine? my Husband!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Therefore no more of him, what Woman, when
Her youth boils up, and wantons in her veins,
When her hot, panting pulse beats to the joy,
And the thin blood springs forward to be gone,
What woman then would quench a generous flame,
In an unactive, heavy Husbands Arms,
That tires and jades your Expectation,
In the first stretch of Love, then dully falls
To his old Trot, and drudges out the Course?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: I do not understand you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Well, No more
Of the dull Subject; Is't not so?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Lorenzo—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: True Madam: And to leave you without Cause,
As you say Madam without Cause, (and sure
You are the best Judge of such a Cause:)
Was barbarous, and did deserve that Fate.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Alass! what Fate?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Come, come: I know the Sex;
And know there is a Spirit in the blood
Of all you marry'd Women, that ne're fails
Solliciting your thoughts to a Consent,
Of forking out your vengeance on the Brows
Of the forgiving, thoughtless Fools at home.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Our Sex may merit Censure: But I hope
My Lord, You think some honest.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I believe
Pride may do much to keep the body safe,
Or fear of vent'ring upon joys unknown:
But she who once has tasted of the Sweets,
(If honest to the love of Truth:) must own
A relish still remaining of the joy,
That plays upon the Pallat, and invites
A youthful Appetite to taste agen:
But when it comes to that, your Cravings grow
Intemperate, not to be satisfi'd.
Oh for the Brawn! the Back of Hercules!
With all the three nights sweat, his father Jove
Spent in Alcmene's service, but to try
If that could satisfie a Ladies longing.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Alass! there is some meaning in your words
I do not apprehend: but yet I fear.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I know thou dost: The Devil that taught thee Sin,
And train'd thee to perfection in thy Trade,
Now leaves thee to the Conscience of thy Crimes.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Alass! What Crimes! am I suspected then?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: No. Prov'd, Confirm'd, Recorded in my Brain.
And I will think thee Over twice a Day,
To warn me of the Dangers of thy Sex.
Suspected! Oh Hypocrisie of Hell!
Tho' thy feign'd tears have seal'd Alphonso's eyes,
With a fond Faith of Thee, thy Truth and Love:
Thou couldst not grosly think, that all the world
Lookt with dull Eyes, thro' an Eclipse, upon Thee.
But 'tis the spight and policy of Hell,
First to seduce, and tempt into the Sin,
And then betray us to the scourge and shame.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: O! I had dy'd contented with the Loss
Of my lov'd Lord.—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Think, think on him!

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: O he is never absent from my Thoughts.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Think what a Creature he would make of thee,
Did he but barely guess at what I know.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: What is't you know?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Away, away, vile Woman! She follows him weeping.
How her eyes stream! Tho' they have long prophan'd
The Sanctity, and pious use of tears;
Yet now in pity to thy Soul, if they
Weep penitence, for mercy on thy Sins,
May they still flow, and wash thy stains away.
But thou hast forc'd me from my Faith, and left
Me hoodwink't, blindly stumbling upon doubts
Of thee, and all thy Sex: Therefore away,
Leave me! be gone, Thou Woman.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Yes, I will
To death, or banishment: But I have vow'd
Never to quit this hold, till you consent
To hear me!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Hear you! Say I should Consent;
What can you say? nay, if you should speak truth,
(Which certainly you wo'n not) and confess
The Circumstances, how you learn't the trade,
The time and place, the Clients you have had;
Nay, and how often they have fee'd you too:
What comfort can this bring? Can this atone
For that soul Mark of shame, that Custom brands
For Womens sins, on their wrong'd Husbands Brows?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Heaven knows how I am injur'd!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And Heaven knows
How glad my heart would be to find you so:
But last night. Think of that.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Alass! I do;
My grief will keep it ever in my mind.
But what? what of last night?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Was it well spent?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: In tears and sorrow for—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: The Disappointment
Your lewd Adulterer, Alberto, met with.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: O Guard of Innocence!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Nay, to deny it,
With Curses minted in the mouth of Hell,
May add to thy Damnation—but not clear
Thee from the living proofs, these Eyes have given me.
Last night I saw him.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: How? where?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Like a Thief,
I saw him steal away from out your House,
And had rewarded then his Treachery,
But Conscientious Clara, scouting round,
And dreading the Event, ran in, and—

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: What?
Has she been practising my ruin too?
What has she said? I see the snares are set,
And Innocence is doom'd to fall a prey
To the mad Censure of licentious Tongues,
But I defie the worst, what has she said?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Who Madam? trusty Clara, nothing she?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Then send for her, and wrack her for the truth;
She has a Womans weakness in her Soul.
That cannot look upon the face of Death,
Without a fear that will discover all.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Ha! if guilty? why should she invite
This tryal, that would make her falshood plain.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: If then you find me foul; if she but hint
A doubt of folly, in my course of life,
Last night, or any time, the way you mean,
By the fair hope of my eternal Soul,
I'le bow me to the Justice of your Sword,
Think you the holy Priest that offers up
My blood, to satisfie my injur'd Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I know not what to think.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Alass my Lord!
I know you have condemn'd me in your thoughts,
And I must own,
The Circumstance shews guilty on my side.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: His entring of your house—

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: At midnight too—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Must come no doubt from some encouragement.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Alas, I only know my Innocence!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Well, I am satisfi'd foul play's design'd,
And Clara deals the Cards to cheat us all.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: If that were prov'd—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I speak not yet of proof,
But when she saw Alberto joyn'd with me,
She started, with confusion in her looks.
As fearing a Discovery.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Indeed.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Let her not know what I have utter'd to you,
For much depends on that

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Oh Heav'n protect the Innocent, and bring
These midnight Treacheries to open day!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: All shall be well agen, as yet your Lord
Is ignorant of what is past; nor durst
I trust his temper, lest his violence
Might urge him on some desperate attempt,
To ruin all: But Madam, when he hears
From me the story of your injur'd Truth,
Swift as a Lovers Wish, expect him here:
'Tis He must prove my Advocate, and plead
A Pardon for the faults my Tongue has made. [Exit.]

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: A pardon! Oh may Heaven in Thunder send
A general pardon to the sinning World;
That every Heart may feel what mine does now;
Alphonso comes; like Natures God, he shows
In a May-morning thro' the Golden Boughs,
Crown'd with the blushing Beauties of the Spring,
Whilest Creatures of all kinds their Tributes brings;
And Birds untaught, his joyful Welcome sing.

l.hi: And all my past misfortunes did but prove
The Purgatory to this Heav'n of Love.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: SIR, I must leave you awhile.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: How Sir, with all your heart? why then perhaps
You don't care for my Company:

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O most infinitely Sir, as naturally as a Woman loves a Fiddle
And a Fool: I shan't dance till you return agen.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Why Sir, you don't take me for a Fool or a Fidler?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Still you're in the wrong:
But that's the common infirmity of long Beards,
Heaven and a Barber may mend all.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: A delicate witty fellow this: I love him dearly, dearly well by Jupiter: But 'tis an ill-natur'd Toad: A Pox of his ill nature: But your great Wits must have a relish that way. But as I was saying, I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Your pleasure Sir.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: My pleasure Sir, no Sir. 'Tis not my pleasure, Why what a plaguy, testy, troublesome, quarrelsome Puppy 'tis.— [aside.]
sp.l: Perhaps 'twould please me better to stay here!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O business must be obeyed.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Sayst thou so?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: By all means.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: I gad, and thou'rt i'th'right on't agen:
