But I shall suddenly return.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: The sooner the better.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: By Jupiter, it goes against my Conscience to part with thee:
I am sorry for't: but I must leave thee.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Art thou my old Lad?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Heartily sorry.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: An Onion will express it at your Eyes.
For me, tho' I shall be a loser by your absence,
The thought on't moves not much.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Not move you! Why Sir, are you not sorry for my absence?

sp.speaker: Alph
sp.l: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: You are not sorry then?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Not I. There's a Philosophical Cataplasm in my Grandmothers Dispensatory, exceeds a Plantane Leaf for a broken-shin.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Ay, may be so. But what of that?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Why that serves me well enough upon these Occasions.
Patience! Sir, patience!
Every man has his liking.—But I prefer Patience to a Post-horse.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Patience is a virtue indeed.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O ever in a mad Dog!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Why in a mad Dog pray?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Hypocrisie, that over-rules the world,
Will have it so, things are not what they seem!
Go to the Pulpits, there you'l hear of patience;
But if you think to find it in the Church,
You'l lose your labour: Mark the Clergies looks,
And you would swear that every Priest ingross't
That virtue to himself, when to speak truth,
'Tis not their Fasting, Watching, or their Prayers,
But envy at the next fat Benefice,
That pines 'em into Ghosts: Nay Fools themselves
Are not contented with their Lot: For I
My self would be a Knave, if I knew how
To set the Mill a going.—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: An admirable Fellow this! Gad I love and honour him, for preaching against the Priests: I warrant him a man of Parts, and of my own Religion: But you'l pardon me, I must away—But Sir, as I was saying, you may be very private here; nothing will disturb your meditations, till I see you agen.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I thank your care!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Your Servant Sir.— [Exit.]
This must be that Rogero, whom my friend
So oft has spoke of: Well, he knows me not,
Nor my design: But thinks my few, poor Brains
Lie under the Dominion of the Moon,
And this Disguise appears the Livery
My folly wears, as she grows to the full.
I must not stir abroad before my hour,
'Tis yet too early for the Duke; at Nine,
Thin follow'd in the Belvidere, he takes
His morning walk: The pleasure of the shade
May tempt him from his followers to the Grove,
And there I'le meet him, and make vengeance sure.
I hear some coming this way: It may be this old mans Daughter,
I've heard much of her, and would know her. [retires.]

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You come most luckily: But I must blush
That, what the obedience of a Child should hide,
I must reveal, a Parents sin and shame.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Is she still obstinate!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Inflexible,
Not to be mov'd by Virtue or by Love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: When comes Alberto here?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Too well I know my Mothers diligence
Will take th'advantage of my Fathers absence,
And give him this occasion.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And I know
There's an intemperate Devil in his Blood,
That never slips an opportunity
Where Virtue may be bought, or Woman ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Is there no way to 'scape him?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yes, a fair one,
What I have satisfi'd you in before;
Becoming well our Sexes Charity,
To a weak Womans wrongs; 'tis what you may
Without a stain of honour undertake,
To free your self, and give me an occasion
To oblige the man I love, perhaps reclaim him.

sp.speaker: Mother within.
sp.l: Angelline! Why Child?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: My Mother calls,
I have not time to hear your story out,
But I am half instructed; pray withdraw
And prompt upon occasion. [Juliana withdraws.]

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: O! Have I found thee?
Thou seest Child, a Mothers Love attends upon thee always.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I thank you for your Care.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Ay, Angelline! I am a careful Mother, up early, and down late, Contriving for thy good, how to make thee a Woman, Child?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: A few years Forsooth will bring that about,
Without breaking your rest for't.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: 'Tis a forward age indeed: I my self was not very backward in my youth, no Novice at thy Years: Fifteen was an age of Information with me, that when my heart panted, and my eye was pleased, could tell me what I wanted without an Interpreter: But Angelline!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Forsooth.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: I would make a happy Woman of thee Child!
And to that purpose I have sent to my Lord Alberto!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: How mother? He has no business here.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But I shall find him an imployment if he comes. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
No business here! away! I see your ignorance; and 'twill Become you to be instructed by me,
For I have run thro the experience of many years: I have made shrew'd observations in my time, Mankind has been my study, and I warrant you 'twould do your heart good to hear me read a Lecture on every part about 'em; I'm Critical in every Point, a nice Distinguisher of the several Ages, Statures, and Dispositions of men, nay the Colour of their Eyes, and Hair cannot escape me... And for the true performing Complexion—I will live and dye in the perswasion of dark brown.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Nothing in commendation of a long Nose? [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You are very knowing Mother.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: And thou shalt learn: I have provided thee a Master that will instruct thee, and in that easie Method, thou wilt wish still to be task't with Lessons of his Love.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Indeed I fain would learn, but yet I fear.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Fear nothing Angelline: Fear nothing: What! let the worst come to the worst a man's but a man, and a Fiddle for favour. I think I hear him within.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: But Mother I shall so blush! I cannot think of shewing him my face— I must be veil'd.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Well, Well. The Business of your Face is over.
There's something else can entertain a Lover. [Exit.]

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You may appear Juliana. I have urg'd this Business
To a quarrel, and you must bear the brunt on't.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am preparing for the incounter—
This Veil transforms me to Angelline: But yet—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Why do you sigh?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis pity to deceive him.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: What if I took this Business on my self?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Not for the world Angelline.—
But if I were a Maid agen.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You would not venture.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Indeed I ought not, but I feel I should—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You wou'd be wiser.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Only while he pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I hear 'em coming. To your posture.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Farewel.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Adieu. Angelline retires. And Juliana stands veil'd in Angellines place.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: At last the tedious date of hopes, and fears
Is at an end, and she is all my own.
O let my arms thus press thee to my heart,
That labours with the longings of my love,
Struggles, and heaves, and fain would out to meet thee.
But why this Veil? why dost thou hide thy face?
Not answer me?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Alass! poor Child! I warrant you her thoughts run all another way. Speak to him Angelline.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: She turns away.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: No, no, my Lord! She's only confounded with her Passion.
Child, one word to save thy Mothers life. — To Ang.
She says, She's so mightily confounded, To Alber.
She knows not what to say.
Alass! you know Maids must have their fits of modesty,
Besides at present you may better spare her tongue,
You will have talking time enough hereafter.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O you instruct me Mother.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: This way, this way, my Lord!
Now Child, but shew thy self thy Mothers Daughter.
You will be gentle to her at the first:
Bate but a little of your Lordships vigour: She's young
And tender, and cannot bear, alass! what we can bear!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: She points me to the Door.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: And chides your stay. Away my Lord, away. Ex. Alberto with Juliana, the Mother following.

sp.speaker: Ang
sp.p: Thus far I'm safe: But how to secure my self for the future, from his Importunities, and my Mothers Unnatural Office—I am you to learn. If I should tell my Father, he is rash, and may do some violence to my Mother. And tho she has put off a Parents Love, I cannot the Obedience of a Child. I must not be seen; here's a Door open. I'le in, and hide my self till the business be over. Goes in to Alphonso.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: God forgive me—I've staid too long from the Gentleman. But his understanding is none of the wisest—And hee'l excuse me without a Complement.— I think I hear him.—Well, he's a Companion for an Emperour.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O Angelline! It is impossible to say how much I love thee.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Mercy upon me! my Angelline with Alberto! Aside.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The Extasie still triumphs in my heart,
My very thought's so full of love, and thee,
That words want meaning to express my joy.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: That Extasie! what does he mean now?
But I'le be with him, and his Extasie.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Give me thy blushes. Throw away that Veil,
That darkens sight, and feast my longing Eyes:
Come! shew me, ha! See's Rog.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Yes! She can shew my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Rogero here!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: And it seems you have seen the Show: But before you and I part, you shall pay for your peeping.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Now Impudence, assist me!
Rogero, Thou see'st I make bold in thy absence.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: For which in your presence, and in the presence of all the world, I will make bold to cut your Throat.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What dost thou mean man?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Nay, If you are thereabouts: What do you mean by your Extasies?
Is my Daughter an Interpreter for your hard words?
But, If you be for your Extasies,
I'le Extasie you, with a Pox at the end on't.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Your Daughter! your Daughter may in time.—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Here's a Dog. Here's a Rogue for you.—But draw Sir, draw.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If I stay, I shall be discovered,
I'le 'een sneak off with what I have got, and be thankful.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: You Gentlewoman! Whither away so fast?
If you dance you must pay the Fidler.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Would I were fairly rid of this old Fellow,
sp.p: I have no stomach to murder the Father, when the Daughter has made me so handsome an entertainment already! Rogero, I won't fight with thee, prithee put up thy Sword.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Then will I Cage thee, and raise an Estate at six pence a piece by shewing thee thro all Italy for a Mahumetan Whoremaster as thou art.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Come, come you trifle time.—I must go by.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: This is your way.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Nay then! Draws.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: With all my heart. But first, Thou most intemperate Placket-Monger! I here declare for the service you have done me in my Daughter there.— I will lye with your whole Family, from your great Grandam, do you see, down to her fourth Generation in Leading-strings.—I'le do't Sir, I'le do't. But come Sir. Have at you Sir.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Think but a little.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: 'Tis to no more purpose. I won't Sir, I won't.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I would not kill thee. Rog. presses Alberto, Lorenz. enters between 'em.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: So! Now I can fairly make my retreat. Farewel, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Lorenzo! My Lord. Why don't you see there, my Daughter there Why she has been—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What art thou mad?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: And shall he carry it off thus?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ay, ay, ay. 'Tis so. He's perfectly distracted. He foams already at the mouth. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What of thy Daughter man?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: O nothing, nothing at all my Lord.
But I shall never have such an opportunity agen.
But come hither Mistriss, 'o mine: Thou most abominable Angelline!
Come and confess—Nay, nay, off with your Veil, and appear
In the true likeness of a Strumpet, and — Pulls off her Veil.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why this is not Angelline.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Not my Daughter!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: By Jupiter, I am glad on't with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Alass! I am a poor unhappy Creature!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Ay, ay. Any thing with all my soul Madam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Betray'd by th'injustice of my Fate,
And a believing Womans easiness,
To the sure ruin of Alberto's Love.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Love Madam. What should a young Lady do but Love?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How I came here, and by what accident
He call'd me Angelline, your Daughter can inform you.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: No body doubts it Madam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Pray be not angry.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: I was never better pleas'd in my life,
Never since I was born, Madam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I hope Sir you'l the easier pardon me.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Pardon! Why, I'le come upon my knees to you. But I'le never forgive my self, never Madam: For coming in like an old Fumbling-Coxcomb, so unseasonably to spoil sport: If you had said but the least word to me, I would have held the Door in a civil way, and been thankful for the Office.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What turn Pimp Rogero?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: In the humour I am in, I could Pimp, Lie, Hold the Door, or do any thing for any body—
But my Lord, I am glad y'are come. The finest Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Here in the next room. He's somewhat Philosophically given, and hates Company, especially Womens Company; for which Reason I am the easier inclin'd to entertain him in my Family.
sp.l: Oh here he comes; Enter Alphonso and Angelline
He's a great Scholar, and a very wise man.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Is not that Angelline with him?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Ay. Tis so indeed—'Tis Angelline.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: If his wisdom hath found the Philosophers Stone in your House: You are certainly a made Man.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: If my Daughter has: I am sure she's made a Woman.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: What I have heard, and you confirm me in, shall turn to your advantage, do not doubt me.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Sir. Goes to Alph.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I am glad you are return'd

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Sure I should know that voice.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I have discovered here.—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Ay, So have I, a Rascal.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ha! Lorenzo there!
Then to my best disguise! Aside.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: You're for the Philosophers Stone as I take it;
Is my Daughter turn'd Chymist?
Does she club with you in the Experiment?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Or are you a Tutor to instruct her in the Liberal Arts?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Of whoring I believe, and I will as liberally
Reward him for his pains.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh hold! for Heaven's sake hold, and hear me;
I may redeem you from this Error.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: 'Tis to no more purpose.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: 'Tis some mistake, and you must hear her.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Nay, if I must, and it be but a mistake,
I care not if I do.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: If he discover me in this disguise
How shall I stand it! or how answer him
To all those Questions, that his Doubts will raise?
If he suspect my Purpose: Why, what then?
Tho' his Suspitions fed upon his Truth,
And his clear Eye in spreading Characters
Read here upon my Forehead my Designs,
He knows I wou'd go on. Aside.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: This has indeed the face of Likelihood.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Of Truth it self: 'Tis impossible it should be otherwise.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Rogero! I would be private.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Not with my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: No, no: With this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: With all my Heart. I'le examine this business within.
Tho' I believe the Philosopher is no better than he should be.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I'le pass my word for him. Exit. with Ang. and Jul.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I thank you Sir, and take my leave. Going to the Door, starts and turns.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ha! I am discovered! Well, Alphonso then.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You start and seem disordered.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Glad of what, Lorenzo!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Glad to find thee firm and constant to thy self,
To find thee still the man I ever lov'd;
Just, Valiant, Honest, Loyal, and my Friend!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O I am nothing, when not thine, thy Friend.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I know thou art my Friend: And therefore I
Am glad to find thee and thy mind at peace;
Thy thoughts are all clear, as Chrystal Current Stams,
In wanton play, coursing each other down,
From the fair Fountain of an honest soul.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I never thought him troublesome till now. Aside

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: 'Tis so: But I will cast beyond him yet.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Wou'd I were rid of him.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: All is not well within Friend!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Never better.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Come, come in vain you stifle a Concern
That most appears, when you hide it most.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Concern! Prithee no more. I know of none.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: This seeming may acquit you to the world,
But not to me: Be satisfi'd, I know you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Why then you know me, and be satisfi'd.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Tho' I have grounds sufficient for my doubts,
I would not rashly entertain a thought
That thou wouldst use false dealing with thy Friend!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: This is unkindly urg'd!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Then answer me,
Why this disguise? and I not know the Cause,

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O Friend! no more of that: There is a Cause,
And I would have thee think, when I conceal
my self from thee, that then (if possible)
I would for ever hide me from my self,
And all the World.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: May I not know that Cause?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I'm ill at ease
At present, most unhappy in my thoughts;
Unfit for many words: When next we meet—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: When next we meet! Alphonso have a care.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Of what Lorenzo?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Come! 'Tis poorly done
To trifle with your Friend. And let me tell you—

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Nay if you grow warm: Farewel.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You go not hence.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Till I am better known to your Designs.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Away, no more of this.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Then be advis'd.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Last night, you may remember, I was left
Under the hard oppression of my doubts;
And left by you in my extreamest need,
When only you cou'd satisfie my thoughts,
And yet I question'd not.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: My Business then
Was yours, your peace of mind.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: So mine is now!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I'le give you Reasons why I then conceal'd it.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: My Reasons you shall have hereafter,
Why mine is now conceal'd. Going.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Nay, then 'tis plain;
And mark me what I say, you sha'not go.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: How! sha'not go?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: By Heav'n you sha'not go.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Who shall oppose my way?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Sir, You may buy
The knowledg dear, to bring it to the proof.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Prithee forbear: This may be dangerous.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: False Friendship's always so.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Yet that Friendship,
False as it is; instructs me how to bear!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Yes, you can bear, now you can calmly bear;
But 'tis with the same Cunning, that the Wolf
Puts tameness on, to abuse the Shepherds care:
But I shall watch you for the Duke—

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: The Duke?
What of the Duke?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: No more of him: Alphonso
Take but a Minutes patience, and I will
Discover to your Ear—

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Am I not wrong'd?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You are.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No matter then for more Discoveries.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And you would be reveng'd?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Reveng'd! I will
By Heaven, I will be to the full.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And may,
You may, with safety, wou'd you hear me out:

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Words are the Crutches, which tame Cowards use,
To halt upon, in any brave Design:
I am resolv'd; and may the Husbands Curse
Light here upon my Forehead, for the Boys
To find me out by, as I pass along,
The common scorn, and jest of laughing Fools:
When I desist from my resolv'd revenge.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Desist! No Friend, I come not now to preach.
A sufferance to thee; but to be imploy'd,
To share thy Fortune, and assist thy Cause!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Dost thou joyn with me? Then I draw my Sword,,
Secure, and confident of my revenge:
Tho' he were great as the first Caesar was,
High Seated in the Empire of the World,
With Nations waiting round him for his Guard,
He went to nothing. All his glories here
Should meet their Fate, and fall before my fury.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Be temperate.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Now let the Tyrant boast;
Pride his vain thoughts, and triumph in his ills;
Grow riotous, and wanton in the spoils
Of the fair Fame of Noble Families;
And let his Bawds, that are abroad for prey,
Fatten his lust with fresh variety, and wrack him on the fury of desire,
That I may take him in the hour of Hell,
And seal Damnation to him in his Blood.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Alphonso, This is all a Mad-man's rage.
Will you yet hear me?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: There's such an Inspiration of revenge,
Rages within my Breast,
That I could stand an idle Looker-on,
Tamely behold his Bawdy Ministers
Dish up my Wife agen to his hot youth,
And then my Sister, for his second Course;
Rather than miss my Time. But this is talk:
Now for the Duke.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Nay then, I can no more.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Why dost thou draw thy Sword?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: To kill thee.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: How! Is this thy Friendship!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Yes. The highest proof!
If thou art fond of Death, fall Nobly here;
Not like a Villain, by the Hangman's hands.
Stir not a step this way, for by the life
Of my eternal Soul, I mean my Words.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: You dare not mean 'em.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Do not prove my Daring,
For if you do.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Nay then— Just engaging.
Yet I am calm. Is this a friend, Lorenzo?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Yes! A just one,
A Friend to Thee, thy Honour, and thy Name.
A Friend, that does deserve a Nobler usage.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I know thou dost deserve what man can merit:
Bear with my weakness; I have been too blame:
But pardon me, and use me like a Friend.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: As I have always done, and ever will.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Then tell me which way I must steer my Course?
Thou would'st not have me spend a sordid life
In a tame Fellowship with my Disgraces?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Nor would I have our generous Duke
Fall violently under thy revenge,
When Justice calls it on Alberto's life.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Yes. I speak on certainty,
On my own Sence: And therefore came to find you;
Had you been temperate, you had sooner known it.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Thou hast redeem'd my Soul from such a Sin,
As only, an abandon'd Conscience, leagu'd
With Hell, could have found out to damn me. Oh!
My Souls Preserver: How shall I repay thee?
What shall I say? Oh there is yet behind
The Quiet, or the Torment of my life;
I dare not ask thee, But if she be false—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Thy Wife! Thy too much wrong'd Wife is innocent;
I've prov'd and found her innocence.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Yes. I have promis'd you shall see her.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: See her, My Friend! Why is she innocent?
O let the Tongues of Angels tune that word,
When they speak comfort to despairing Souls:
For there are Charms in every Letter there:
The very Winds in silent Reverence,
Must listen to the Music of that Sound,
And bear about the Accents of my joy.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Come! You delay.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I had forgot my self.
I thought I only dream't of Happiness:
And fear'd to wake to wretchedness agen.
But lead me to her: O I do confess
I am too blame: Now, when my sparing Fate
Hardly allows me a few happy Hours,
To trifle out my Minutes idly here;
When Love invites me with his softest Charms,
To improve my Joys in my Erminia's Arms.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Who calls upon Erminia!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: See, your Wife
Impatient of her longings, comes her self
To meet your steps, and bless you on your way.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: My Wife Lorenzo!

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: O 'tis Heaven to hear
On any Terms, that dear lov'd voice agen:
Though my misfortunes ever must despair
Of any Comfort from those Lips: Yet speak
Or if you will be gentler to my Prayers. Kneels.
Speak Kindly to me. Speak as you were wont;
With those undoing Charms upon your Tongue;
That have so often trembled to my Soul,
In the soft Rapture of protesting Joys!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Can you hear this, yet see her on her knees?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Alass! I am unworthy, do thou raise her;
And tell her Friend, the guilty memory,
How I have wrong'd her innocence, turns my Brain,
And fixes me a sensless Statue here.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Then I will rush upon you with my Charms,
Break thro' the Bars of Modesty and Form,
To your Assistance: Thus to fold you in,
And with my Passion warm you into Life!
My Love! My Soul!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: My being! all that Heav'n,
From the deep Councils of Eternity,
Could have sent down his Blessings on Mankind
To sweeten life, and beautifie the world.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why this is as it should be!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O my Friend!
How is my peace indebted to thy Care?
And how Erminia, how shall I reward
Thy Virtue? How intreat thee to forget
Thy wrongs?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: I know of none.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Their memory!

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: I have no thought, but of my instant joy,
Of Love, and Thee.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Thou art too good for man—
But thy Example shall instruct my Love,
And make me worthy of Thee.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: O for this!
May the recorded Perjuries of men,
Ne're meet a Faith in our believing Sex!
To injure the swift progress of their joys:
Men are all Truth, all Constancy, all Love:
And they who do traduce their Virtues, wrong
Their Consciences: But yet it does belong
To th'envious Old, so to instruct the Young.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: And for thy sake, may listning Virgins find
Their Lovers just, as thy Alphonso's kind.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: And you, who hear the Story of our Lives,
May you have all such Husbands—

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: And such Wives.—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: WEll! well, I am satisfi'd. I love Reason, and am easily perswaded in the way of Reason, or so: A little of it goes a great way with me; and when once I find it, why the Dispute's at an end.—I give it over, I am silent, not a word, not a syllable? Mum for me!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Indeed you have heard the Truth of what I know?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Nothing has been omitted.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Why very well—You see I am satisfi'd.
But how the world may be mistaken in a Philosopher!
sp.p: Angelline! Come hither. Come, I must take you to task a little upon the Point, or so. Nay, look thy natural Father in the face Child. Why this same Alphonso looks like a vigorous Rogue upon occasion: He had thee alone, that he had: Prithee how did he behave himself? Ha! what I warrant you, he kis't you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: No indeed!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: What did he not kiss you? Put you to the squeak, or so;
Tickle you, tumble you — Or —

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: No Sir, Nothing of all these.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Why, what a Pox, neither kiss, tickle or tumble, fumble or mumble you? What did he not offer you a Testimony of his Manhood, Child?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I do not understand you!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Nay, no Blushes for the matter! a man may do that in a civil way To shew his Breeding, Child: That he may, and no harm done.
sp.l: But for Alberto—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sir, May he do so?

sp.speaker: Rog,
sp.l: Ay, and be whipt thro'the Guts too for his pains, Madam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I hope not so.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Nay, I should be sorry for't: That's the truth on't: But I heard Alphonso talk something suspitiously that way.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O Sir, If you have pity for misfortune,
Fly, and prevent this mischief: I have told you
The Cause of these mistakes. Clara, and I
Have been too blame: But he is innocent.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Nay, I am easily mollifi'd: I love an honest Whoremaster with all my Heart, that I do; and as far as old Roger will go, by Jupiter, it shall be at his service. But we must make haste, that we must— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: You know my purpose: Therefore be advis'd,
And manage this Design with your best Art;
I know your Letter soon will bring him here;
'Twill Conjure him, from his cool honest thoughts,
Into the warmer Circle of your Arms.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Alass! What means this preparation?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ha! What means that Question now? Is this a Time?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: If I am doubted!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: If I were a man,
Or any thing, but a fond Womans Fool,
A Husband, Death! you durst not trifle thus!
Why will you drive my Nature to extreams?
Would you not have me satisfi'd?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: I would.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: This is the only way.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: I fear th'Event.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Th'Event, of what? what is that you fear?
Have you a Cause of fear?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: I have a near one,
Dear as my peace, and far above my life,
Your safety is the Cause of all my fears.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No more—I hear him coming, you receive him
As I advis'd: You know the rest.— Retires.

div.head: A SONG written by Sir George Ethridge.

lg.l: SEe how fair Corinna lies,
Kindly calling with her Eyes:
In the tender Minute prove her;
Shepherd! Why so dull a Lover?
Prithee, Why so dull a Lover?
In her blushes see your shame;
Anger they with Love proclaim;
You too coldly entertain her:
Lay your Pipe a little by,
If no other Charms you try,
You will never, never gain her.
While the happy Minute is,
Court her, you may get a kiss,
May be, favours that are greater:
Leave your Piping, to her fly,
When the Nymph you love is nigh,
Is it with a Tune you treat her?
Dull Amintor! fy, Oh! fy:
Now your Shepherdess is nigh;
Can you pass your time no better?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: So the kind Nymph, dissolving as she lay,
Expecting sigh'd, and chid the Shepherds stay:
When panting to the Joy, he flew, to prove
The Immortality of Life and Love.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: I must, but know not how to Act this Part.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Turn not away: I see the God of Love
Is busie in thy heart; He shoots his fires
Through every Pore, and kindles every Vein,
And now he mounts in blushes on thy Cheeks,
That tell me all, and summon on my joy.
Say Madam, is't not so?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Nay, now my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Your looks confess it: Every glance declares
For Love and me; Whilest your hot glowing Eyes,
Like golden Planets flaming from their Sphears,
Shine out, and guide me safe into your Arms.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Why do you talk thus to me?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I confess I am too blame,
When this kind opportunity informs me,
There are a Thousand better Arguments,
Of more convincing Virtue to prevail,
Than all the unperforming sensless noise,
That talking love can offer to the Fair.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: You wrong my meaning still.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I would not wrong it:
Nor injure you so far, to think you can
Mean otherwise: Away, this modesty
Is the dull Virtue of a Marriage Bed;
The Idol only of a Husbands Zeal!

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: A Husband! Then my Fit returns agen.
Why did you name him?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Nay the Devil knows.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: At the least mention of that word, I start,
And the remembrance of my sufferings
Freezes my blood, and leaves me pase with fear.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: There is no danger in a Lovers Arms.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: But did you know what I have suffer'd!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: All, I've heard it all, and know the unlucky Cause,
The Letter that I sent—

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: What Letter?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: That, that fell into Alphonso's hands.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: I've seen one from the Duke.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: It was from me.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Is't possible from you?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The Story shall imploy an idler hour,
And Satisfie you in each Circumstance;
Why I subscrib'd the Duke to my Design.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: I dread the Consequence. Aside.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: You see the straits
The hazardous attempts, that ventrous Love
Ingages on his way to Happiness:
Yet these are nothing now, tho' I have tired
The Expectation of a Chymists hope,
This Golden Birth at last rewards my Toil.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Forbear, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Forbear!

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: I must not hear you.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Think who I am?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Whose Wife I am.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: For that it matters not: Since you are mine.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: O unexampled villany— Aside.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: But why?
O! why these scruples now? I thought last night
Had satisfi'd all doubts.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Last night, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Nay, then I must refresh your memory!

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: This Insolence is Brutal.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Tho' I find
Your purpose plainly meant to my abuse,
I think the management of your Design,
Exceeds the peevish follies of your Sex:
Alass! We might have parted upon easier Terms;
For Faith you wrong me, Madam, if you think
I came to find out Constancy, or Preach
It to a Woman. I've been your Guest indeed,
Have met a hearty Welcome; and last night,
That Bawdy night, and honest Clara knows
I have not been ungrateful: So, I leave you
To the fresh youth of your next Customer.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Thy own words be thy Sentence!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: How? Betray'd!

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: My fears are come upon me; O some power
Divert this mischief! Help for Heaven's sake! help. Runs out.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No Humane help can come between thy Lusts
And my revenge: Despair, and Curse thy self.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: You wo' not murder me?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: 'Tis Justice now
That arms against thy Crimes, and strikes in me:
Therefore, prepare—

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Yet throw away your odds;
And do not basely thus attempt my life.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: That baseness is your own: For face to face,
When brave men shew their Actions to the Sun,
You could not wrong my Honour, or my Name,
But by base practises, and midnight Arts,
You found the weakness of a Womans Guard,
And there surpriz'd me, take the just Reward— The Pistol not going off,—draws his Sword.
Fortune I thank thee: Thou instructs my rage.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I wish no more Advantage. Now come on.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: This brings thy certain Fate.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: That's yet to try.— Fight.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Thy blood shews thou art mortal: Yet unsay
What thou hast said.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Were Fate within thy power,
I'd scorn my life at such a sordid price.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Then have thy Wish: O were the Strumpet here,
That my just Sword might joyn your Bodies close
As your glew'd Lusts.—This, Villain to thy Heart, Fight, Alb. falls.
Thou hast it there; and she shall quickly follow. Going out, justles Rogero at the Door.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Why, what a Pox, here's fine doings indeed!
If Whoremasters fall off at this rate, our Women
Are likely to have a Comfortable time on't, that's
Certain, Maiden-heads may hang as long as our Medlars
Do, and mellow into Marmalet, That they may.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Some help I hope!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: What, you are not kill'd then you say! Only dril'd through
The Guts or so, to cool your Liver, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The loss of blood has made me faint.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Ah! what say you now to the Conjuration of a Black-brow'd
Wench? Would not that raise you, ha?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Your Arm will do it better. Sir I thank you!
But if you would be truly Charitable,
Follow Alphonso; you may yet prevent him,
Tho' he has vow'd the murder of his Wife.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Mercy upon us! why, what a bloody minded Monster
Is a Cuckold in Imagination. Enter Juliana and Angelline.
Oh: You come in time! here lead him in;
Nay, no crying for the matter, Madam: He has
Sprung a leak or so; that's the truth on't: But lend
You but a helping hand, and I warrant him
He serves agen, that he does— Exit.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Juliana here! I know humanity
Instructs the world to pity the distress'd,
But oh! in thee, in thee whom I have wrong'd,
This tenderness, these kind forgiving tears,
Shew most amazing Goodness, far above
The natural frailty of a Womans Love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Abandon'd and forsaken, at my Birth,
Of every Star, I live an outcast here!
Doom'd by my guilty Fate to this curs't day
For thy undoing—I have been the Cause
Of thy misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Thou the Cause! Tho' thou
Art Truth it self; In this I would prefer
The Obstinacy of an Infidel,
And 'twere less sin, than that injurious Faith.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I cannot look upon those bleeding Wounds
Without a fear that sinks me.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I have none,
I hope, that dangerously threaten me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Within, my Story shall confirm, what I
Have said, and satisfie your Doubts.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I go;
Guessing in vain at what I long to know.— Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Alphonso with a Dagger against Erminia.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Nay—'Tis in vain: You should have thought before,
Now 'tis too late.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Oh! why that dreadful Dagger?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No stirring hence: There is no safety for thee!
Think, think what thou hast done.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Alass! Your words
Speak terror to me, and I fear you now!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I know thou dost.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: O! Do not kill me Sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Not kill thee! why, this Impudence exceeds
The measure of thy sins; and nothing but
A dead stupidity that waits on guilt,
Could urge that now: Not kill thee! have a Care,
That thought that flatters thee into a hope
Of Life, betrays thee to Damnation:
For hadst thou Lives in Number to thy Lusts,
Not one should scape me: No, I would not send thee
One last repenting hour to save thy Soul.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Yet hold my Lord—

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: None of your Womans Arts,
To soften my Resolve.—

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Hear me but speak!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Have I not heard enough? Methinks my Ears
Are full of Cuckold still, yet I will hear thee, say
On what foundation canst thou raise a hope
Of mercy? Is't from my Natures sufferance?
A Florentine's forgiveness, thou can'st hope;
Or from the Venial Quality, you whore,
Of your offending. O you Strumpet down!
Down to your lewd Adulterer— Going to stab her.

div.stage: Enter Lorenzo, who interposes and takes the Dagger.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Oh hold, Alphonso—Hold! Are you a man?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Protect her not: For I have vowed her death.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Murder your wise!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: A Whore, a Whore, Lorenzo! practis'd long
In the hot exercise of Letchery,
Ripen'd in Sin, and ready to be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: This is a Mad-mans rage, To be restrain'd
By force if you go on. Draws.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Nay then 'tis plain,
You would maintain her in her Trade?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I will defend her Innocence.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Her Innocence!
Or I am mad, or this will make me so;
Alberto has confess't it, in these Ears
Proclaim'd me Cuckold. Needs there other proof?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Not of his vanity: But I can bring
One more Convincing of her Innocence!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Words, idle words. Lorenzo! give me way.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: It must be through my Breast, if you come on.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Nay, Since it must be so.— Just ingaging Erminia throws her self between 'em.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: O let me here
Attone this difference: Let your fury fall
Upon my life, and cut me from my Woes;
You think me false, my Lord; and in that thought
Are bury'd all my hopes: High Heav'n that knows
My Bosom'd Soul must witness to this truth,
Since Love and you no more, no more are mine;
The Comforts of this life are mine no more,
And death alone can be my Refuge now.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: How's this! Swords drawn upon a Woman: Since
Wars must ensue, I declare for the Subject: Old Rogero
Stands up for the Property of the Petticoat, that's certain:
Speak, what say you?—Is't a Battel Royal, or no?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Prithee be gone! This is no fooling time.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Why very well, Now you say something, Y' have fool'd it long enough in Conscience already; murder your Wife for not making you a Cuckold! By Jupiter, I thought the Devil in the Family!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: How, that agen Rogero?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Nay Sir, I stand to my word, and over and over agen say, that Alberto's an Ass; as a certain Gentlewoman within, one Juliana can testifie at large.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: What dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Mean Sir! Don't you know what I mean? Why then Sir I'le tell you what I mean! In the first place I mean to be heard. And secondly, Tho' it be a little unreasonable, because I trouble you but seldom, I expect to be understood Sir, that I do: For as I was saying, this Juliana out of a regard to her former Acquaintance with Alberto, finding his Designs on the Body of your Wife there; and my Daughter, has out of a Conscionable Discretion supplied their places, and fobb'd him off with her own proper Person.—And there's my meaning out now.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Why this is wonderful, but tell me how?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: How Sir! May be I won't! May be I can't tell you how!
I did not hold the Door, or Pimp to the Project; I,
But there comes a Gentleman can tell you more.

div.stage: Enter Alberto, led by Juliana and Angelline, and her Mother.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Thy Story Juliana has subdu'd
My wilder thoughts, and fixt me only Thine:
Bur oh! Instruct me how I shall appear
Before that injur'd Fair, whose Innocence
Too late I find I have unjustly wrong'd
Beyond a hope of Pardon.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Wrong'd said'st thou? Wrong'd? Lorenzo! Dost thou hear him?
Even he, Alberto! He, who best can tell
If she be so, says that my Wife is wrong'd:
You talk'd of Innocence, whose Innocence? O speak!
Inform me strait, and save me from my fears.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I must confess my wild Intemperance
Urging me on, my busie thoughts were all
Lawlesly loose, and ready for the Spoil
Of Chaste Erminia's Virtue.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ha—What Grounds?
On what Encouragement did you proceed?
Any from her?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Oh never! All I had
Was from my fond perswading vanity:
Till Clara came, and gave me fuller hopes.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: She has confess't her Treachery!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Impudent damning Whore!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Last night my Lord!
You may remember we met here.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: We did.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Came you abroad so late to take the Air?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: 'Twas Clara summon'd me, and I obey'd.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Erminia was the Feast she bid you to!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: That was the Invitation: But I find
I stand indebted for my Welcome here. To Juliana.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: That Clara too confirms.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Why does there need
A farther Proof? —The Circumstances joyn
In full Consent, to clear her to the World. Goes to Ermina.
O let me thus make sure of Happiness!
Thus panting, fold thee in the Arms of Love,
Till my repenting thoughts, and subdu'd fears,
Confessing thy Dominion in my Heart,
Make room to entertain thy Triumph there.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Your Servant, my Lord: Here's a slight Commodity, A Maidenhead here; if your Appetite be up agen: We have stole Custom, and can afford you a pen'worth.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I have paid for that already.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Pray explain your self.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I bought her of that reverend Matron there, her Mother.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Hem! hem! hem.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Rogero! I confess I had design'd
Thy Daughter for my Wife!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: With all my Heart.—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: But since she proves of such a virtuous strain,
And on the surer side, I dare not trust my Honour
With her Mothers Infamy.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Ay, as you say. 'Tis that forb ids the Banes.—Her mother there!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: There is no other Cause?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Here take her then: By Jupiter she's yours.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Only to let you know, That the Prisoner at the Bar there, is no Mother of Angellines; no Matrimonial Consort of mine, but the natural iniquity of my youth.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Your Whore!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: My Concubine, an't shall please you, of starving memory: Whom, when Angellines Mother dy'd, I entertain'd, for the Reputation of being in Fashion, and the Breeding of my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A hopeful Education truly Sir!
But now she is my Care!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Amen to that, with more Devotion than ever the Parish-Priest said it in his Prayers: Why, I am young agen, I could caper, sing, come over a stick, or any thing in the humour I am in.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: I hope you'l pardon me.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Why, what did I set you up for, but to follow your trade? I know a Whore run's as naturally into a Bawd, as a young man into Letchery and the Pox.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Or as an old man into Impotence, and Law Suits: Come Rogero! You must forgive her: You see in all Civil Governments, Bawds, as well as Lawyers past the Exercise of the Bar, are consider'd for their Experience; and both have their Chamber-Practice allowed them, for the Benefit of the Publick.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Nay then your Servant Sir! I am satisfi'd, if the Government allows it: And am satisfi'd 'tis a Civil Government for allowing it. And so your Servant agen.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Our joys are now Compleat.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: By Heav'n they are
So purely perfect, nothing can remain
Worthy a Wish: You two are all the World.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Oh happiness of Life, and Innocence!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: And Innocence is prov'd: Oh there's the thing.
For 'tis a Womans falsest, vainest pride
To boast a Virtue, that has ne're been try'd:
—In equal folly too those Husbands live,
Who peevishly against themselves, contrive
By early fears, to hasten on the Day;
For jealousie but shews our Wives the Way:
And if the forked Fortune be our Doom,
In vain we strive; The Blessing will come home.

div.trailer: The Prologue Written by Mr. John Dryden.
The Epilogue by the Honourable JOHN STAFFORD, Esquire.

lg.l: HOW comes it, Gentlemen, that now aday's
When all of you so shrewdly judge of Plays,
Our Poets tax you still with want of Sence,
All Prologues treat you at your own Expence.
Sharp Citizens a wiser way can go,
They make you Fools, but never call you so.
They, in good Manners, seldom make a slip,
But, Treat a Common Whore with Ladyship:
But here each sawcy Wit at Random writes,
And uses Ladies as he uses Knights.
Our Author, Young and Grateful in his Nature,
Vow's, that from him no Nymph deserves a Satyr.
Nor will he ever Draw—I mean his Rhime,
Against the sweet Partaker of his Crime.
Nor is he yet so bold an Ʋndertaker
To call MEN Fools, 'tis railing at their MAKER.
Besides, he fears to split upon that shelf;
He's young enough to be a FOP himself.
And, if his Praise can bring you all A-bed,
He swears such hopeful Youth no Nation ever bred.
Your Nurses, we presume, in such a Case,
Your Father chose, because he lik'd the Face;
And often they supply'd your Mothecs place.
The Dry Nurse was your Mothers ancient Maid,
Who knew some former slip she ner'e betray'd.
Betwixt 'em both, for Milk and Sugar Candy,
Your sucking Bottles were well stor'd with Brandy.
Your Father to initiate your discourse
Meant to have taught you first to swear and Curse;
But was prevented by each careful Nurse.
For, leaving Dad and Mam, as names too common,
They taught you certain parts of Man and Woman.
I pass your Schools, for there when first you came,
You wou'd be sure to learn the Latin name.
In Colledges you scorn'd their Art of thinking,
But learn'd all Moods and Figures of good Drinking:
Thence, come to Town you practice Play, to know
The Vertues of the High Dice and the Low.
Each thinks himself a SHARPER most profound:
He cheats by Pence, is cheated by the Pound:
With these Perfections, and what else he Gicans,
The SPARK sets up for Love behind our Scenes;
Hot in pursuit of Princesses and Queens.
There, if they know their Man, with cunning Carriage,
Twenty to one but it concludes in Marriage.
He hires some Homely Room, Love's Fruits to gather,
And, Garret high, Rebells against his Father.
But he once dead—
Brings her in Triumph with her Portion Down,
A Twillet, Dressing-Box, and Half a Crown.
Some Marry first, and then they fall to Scowring,
Which is, Refining Marriage into Whoring.
Our Women batten well on their good Nature,
All they can rap and rend for the dear Creature.
But while abroad so liberal the DOLT is,
Poor SPOƲSE at Home as Ragged as a Colt is.
Last, some there are, who take their first Degrees
Of Lewdness in our Middle Galleries:
The Doughty BƲLLIES enter Bloody Drunk,
Invade and grabble one another's PƲNK:
They Caterwoul, and make a dismal Rout,
Call SONS of WHORES, and strike, but ne're lugg-out:
Thus while for Paultrey Punk they roar and stickle,
They make it Bawdier than a Conventicle.

div.head: EPILOGUE, By ANOTHER HAND.
div.l: YOU saw your Wife was Chaste, yet throughly tryd,
And, without doubt, y'are hugely edisy'd;
For, like our Hero, whom we shew'd to day,
You think no Woman true, but in a Play;
Love once did make a pretty kind of Show,
Esteem and Kindness in one Breast wou'd grow,
But 'twas Heav'n knows how many years ago.
Now some small Chatt, and Guinney Expectation,
Gets all the pretty Creatures in the Nation:
In Comedy your little Selves you meet,
'Tis Covent-Garden drawn in Bridges-street.
Smile on our Author then, if he has shown
A jolly Nut-brown Bastard of your own.
Ah! Happy you, with Ease and with Delight,
Who act those Follies, Poets toil to Write!
The sweating Muse does most leave the Chase,
She puffs, and hardly keeps your Pratean Vices pace.
Pinch you but in one Vice, away you fly
To some new Frisk of Contrariety.
You rowl like Snow-Balls, gathering as you run,
And get seven Dev'ls, when dispossess'd of one.
Your Venus once was a Platonique Queen,
Nothing of Love beside the Face was seen;
But every Inch of Her you now Uncase,
And clap a Vizard Masque upon the Face.
For Sins like these, the zealous of the Land,
With little Hair, and little or no Band,
Declare how circulating Pestilences
Watch every Twenty Years, to snap Offences.
Saturn, even now, takes Doctoral Degrees,
Hee'l do your work this Summer, without Fees.
Let all the Boxes, Phoebus find thy Grace,
And, ah, preserve thy Eighteen penny Place!
But for the Pit-Confounders, let 'em go.
And find as little Mercy as the show:
The Actors thus and thus, thy Poets pray;
For every Critick sav'd, thou damn'st a Play.
